Dear Father Lambert:

It has been brought to my attention that arrangements had been made to transfer the two Houle children from the Sandy Bay to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School without authority from the local Indian Superintendent.

In order to maintain friendly relations with the local Indian Superintendent, it is only fair to arrange these matters through his office. This procedure will not hamper the arrangement in any way but will lead to mutual good will.

When recruiting children for the first time you should also consult the local Indian Superintendent in each case in order that he may approach the Department for authority to admit the children as grant-earning pupils.

We have had complaints from local Superintendents that children are brought to the school first and later the Superintendent is asked to recommend the approval of the admission. This is hardly fair to the Superintendent concerned as he is responsible for all the children in his Superintendency.
and there may be cases that he knows about where children need institutional care more than the children picked out by the Missionary.

Please bear this in mind for future transfers and admissions.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mister Phelan:

Your letter of November I last (your file 584-10) seems to indicate that you have been misinformed concerning the transfer of the two Houle children from this school.

It has always been my policy to follow the proper channels in such matters and I want to state that concerning the transfer of the children in question I have duly put an application with Mister Staunton in Dauphin who, to the best of my knowledge has forwarded it to Mister Davis who, in turn, has or should have transferred it to you in Ottawa.

Furthermore, the application I sent in was to the effect that the said children be transferred to the Roman Catholic school at Kenora, Ontario, and not to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, as you have been informed. Whoever has stated that to you certainly was misinformed himself because I cannot see how he could confuse those two institutions.

The application for the transfer of those two children was made in due time, before the school term and it should have been in your office before the opening of the classes. By all means, I can assure you that I did to the best of my knowledge and that I still feel that I have followed the proper channels.

Trusting that this will clarify the question, I am

Yours sincerely,

Mr. J. Rayson,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,

With reference to the applications for the admission of Gilbert Meeches and Roy Francis to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, it will be necessary for you to provide further information on these two applications.

With reference to Gilbert Meeches, it is noted on the application that he attended the Portage la Prairie and Brandon residential schools for eight years. We have checked our records and find that he was admitted to the Brandon school in September 1943 as the application for admission at that time read the religious denomination to be Protestant.

Please advise under what circumstances you recommended the admission of this boy to the Sandy Bay school which is Roman Catholic and what evidence you have to show that this boy is a Roman Catholic as indicated on the application for admission.

With reference to Roy Francis, the application form you signed indicates the religious denomination to be Roman Catholic and that this boy has previously attended the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. We have reviewed our records but fail to find his name on the Portage la Prairie Return for the past six years.

It would be appreciated if you would advise when he attended the Portage la Prairie school and if he actually
attended this school which is United Church, when the parents changed their religious denomination as the application received indicates the religious denomination to be Roman Catholic.

As the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of the two children mentioned above, please advise the Principal of the school that these children should not be admitted to this school until a decision is reached on their applications and if they are at school they should be discharged immediately and returned to their parents.

Attached I am forwarding a copy of a letter sent to Father Lambert in connection with Gilbert Meeches.

With reference to the applications for Selma and Viola Hazel Francis, it is presumed that these girls are sisters of Roy Francis mentioned above, consequently their admissions are denied until such time as the religious denomination of this family is clarified.

Gilbert Meeches: When this application was received in the office from the Principal of the Sandy Bay School, I contacted the father, Archie Meeches, No. 105 of the Long Plain Band, and he advised me to the effect that although he was not Roman Catholic himself, his wife was an adherent to this faith. Jean Lambert, O.M.I.

Roy, Selma and Viola Hamel Francis:
The following are the pertinent facts. When the application was received in this office on March 20th and originally dated January 3rd, I contacted the father, Donald Francis who lives in MacGregor. He advised me to the effect that his wife, Eva, No. 159 of the Long Plain Band, was Roman Catholic and upon further inquiries through the Principal of the Sandy Bay School, I received copies of the Certificates of Baptism as follows:

Viola Hazel Francis: Baptised at the Notre Dame des Suffrages Church on January 3rd, 1952 at Sandy Bay, signed by Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I.

Roy Francis: Certificate of Baptism from the same church as noted above showing the child as being baptised on January 3rd, 1952 at Sandy Bay by Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I. I have checked with the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School and find that Roy attended this school from January 9th, 1949 to September, 1950 and was discharged from the school because of the fact that his father, Donald Francis was living at MacGregor and had secured permanent employment and tuition fees was paid to the MacGregor day school for Roy's attendance.
From conversations I have had with this boy's father, it would not appear that Donald had ever changed his religion, but he advises me that his wife has always been a Roman Catholic as outlined in my para 3.

Viola Selma Francis: A copy of the Certificate of Baptism for the same church showing this girl as being baptised on January 3rd, 1952 at Sandy Bay by Rev. Jean Lambert, O.M.I. has been submitted to this office.

My reason for recommending the admission of the three Francis children was that there is no doubt that their home conditions are not of the best, however, I did advise the principal of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School to the effect that any admissions must be made after approval of the Department. In these particular instances, the children have been in the Sandy Bay School since January 3rd without the knowledge of this office. The mother, Eva Francis, has received Family Allowances for the children which, of course, has resulted in an overpayment and this amount will have to be recovered.

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter, I have contacted Father Lambert by telephone and he has advised that as they are now at home following the Easter recess, they would remain at home until the matter has been completely clarified.

Yours truly,

The Principal of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School in preparing the June Quarterly Return has neglected to forward Form I.A. 411 which should accompany the Quarterly Return when forwarding it to this office.

For pupils 363 and 364 the Principal has claimed 56 days grant while he has shown that they were admitted to the school on May 15, 1952. It will be noted that the school is entitled to 46 days grant for each of the two pupils. We have amended this on the Return.

For pupil 0290 the Principal has claimed 66 days grant and has indicated that she left for Selkirk San on May 31. From this information it is impossible to know how the Principal arrived at the figure 66 as if the pupil was in residence continuously from April 1 to May 31 this would add up to 61 days. It is evident, therefore, that the pupil left for the sanatorium later than May 31st; however, as school is entitled to thirty days hospital grant in such cases, we have allowed 91 days grant for this pupil. Please ascertain from the Principal the exact date when this girl left for the sanatorium.

The Principal has also claimed 66 days for pupil 0309. The information is identical to pupil 0290. We have allowed 91 days for this pupil also. It will be necessary for you to secure same information as for pupil 0290.
The Principal has dropped O382 with no apparent reason. Please advise him that this practice is not correct as each pupil discharged and dropped from the Return must be shown on Form I.A. 411 and authority for discharge secured.

The Principal has claimed 26 days grant for pupils O409 and O410 and has indicated that they were admitted to school on May 15th. It is presumed that these pupils were either truant or were admitted to the school later than indicated by the Principal. As we are anxious to have the Return paid as soon as possible, we are disallowing any Per Capita Grant for the two pupils. It will be in order for the Principal to include them on the September Return indicating the dates they were admitted to the school and the period of their truancy if they were truant.

Please impress on the Principal the necessity of taking great care in preparing the Quarterly Returns. These Returns are checked by the Treasury Branch and the Auditor-General's office and the information must be definitely shown on all absences, giving the number of days the pupils were in residence.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

As we have started a movement of welfare in the form of a girl's club for the ex-pupils of the school of Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, this has proved a decided success and we wish to progress and extend this welfare to all of the Indians on the reserve.

So far A sister has devoted herself to this work, but our staff being limited, we cannot undertake further extensions to this movement with our actual staff. An instructor could be obtained, which we cannot do actually as we are financially handicapped. The work of this instructor will consist in teaching the women to sew, knit, weave and all other handicrafts.

A lot of relief is given actually to the Indians and they dispose of it to their detriment. Under one supervision this could be done away with and would entail quite an economy to the Department, so would appreciate in knowing if the Department could see its way clear in granting a special grant towards this purpose.

The writer would indeed be very pleased to take this matter further personally upon interview and explain in detail the full details of this movement which is already creating a lot of good on the reserve.

Respectfully submitted by,

Very truly yours,

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant and also letter received by you from Rev. Father Comeau, Principal of the Sandy Bay residential school, enclosed therewith.

The request contained in the Principal's letter was brought to the attention of the Department a few weeks ago by Father Plourde. At that time the officials were sympathetically disposed to the appointment of a social worker at Sandy Bay. In view of the new conditions now confronting us, however, it is not at all likely that such an appointment would be even seriously considered. In this period of national crisis it will be the duty of Indian Agents and Principals of Indian day and residential schools to co-operate with the Department in keeping all expenditures down to the lowest possible figure. A rapid advance in the price of certain basic commodities and the limited appropriations at our disposal have created a very embarrassing condition for those charged with the responsibility of administering schools and Indian relief. I feel confident, however, that the members of our field force will do all they possibly can to assist us during this critical period.

Dear Sir,

We have had during the last month the visit of the Public School Inspector, Mr. McKenzie. He suggested that the boys should be trained in more extensive manual labor especially trades, in which our Indian Boys might later on make their way in life. He suggested woodwork and woodcraft, shoemaking, for a beginning.

He directed us to Mr. P.J. Johnstone, Director of Technical Education, Dept. of Education in Winnipeg. The answer from the Technical Bureau was that the Dept. of Education does not provide funds for
equipment for this undertaking.

I wonder if the Indian Department at Ottawa could not be of help in this matter.

For a small workshop, hammers, saws, coping saw, planes, bench vise, chisel, bit brace etc. are needed.

For woodcraft, the Hobbs fretwork outfit and a pedal jigsaw for fretwork would be required.

For the Shoemaker's shop, a sewing machine for shoes, iron foot stands and stool would be of immediate necessity.

The Indian Boys here like to do these small works. From past experience, with just one small saw and a hammer, they managed to make pretty bird houses, but they lack material and experience. We come with the other.

I am inclined to believe that
such equipment might prove of great help to the School Program and to the boys themselves.

Hoping to hear from you soon, I am yours very truly,

Leon Savine,
Boys' Supervisor
Sandy Bay Indian Res. School
Marina P.O., Man.
Ottawa,
December 7, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Leon Savoie in connection with the vocational work at the Sandy Bay Indian residential school. He mentions two activities which the Department is inclined to assist at the present time:

1. For a small workshop -- hammer, saws, coping saw, planes, bench vise, chisels, bit brace etc. are needed.

2. For woodcraft -- the Hobbies Fretwork outfit and a pedal jigsaw for fretwork would be required.

Please let me have detailed information regarding the articles you require for the workshop and the woodcraft.

Mr. Savoie also suggests equipment for a shoemaker's shop. This machinery is expensive and the Department is not prepared to consider supplying it at the present time. As a matter of fact it is doubtful if it is worth while encouraging pupils to learn shoe repairing as it is unlikely that they would have an opportunity of earning their living by doing such work after they leave school. A more practical trade to encourage would be automechanics. It might be possible for you to obtain an old automobile engine without heavy expense and some preliminary training could be given.

Yours truly,

Rev. O. Chagnon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Residential School,
Marius, Man.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Last October, when visiting our School, you asked me to write to you about our Social & Welfare Club established at the Sandy-Bay School for the Indians of the Reserve.

You told me then to mention the material needed for the good operation of this Club.

The most needed apparatus for the moment, is a 60 inches wide loom with accessories. We need also material for the making of blankets for the old Indians; about a hundred pounds of knitted wool, also raw wool for spinning; few hundred pounds.

Request a 60" brown woolen blanket from without frame, would you suggest purchase?

P.P.

5/4/40
There are only two firms I know of from whom foot-power looms such as we have at Caughnawaga can be purchased: Romeo Savoie, Joliette, Quebec; and Omer Leclerc, L'Islet, Quebec. The size mentioned in the attached letter, 60", is unusual, as 30", 45" and 90" looms are the sizes usually made. The price runs about $1.00 per inch and it is necessary to specify that heddles are to be included and the size of reed desired. We have found a reed "15 to the inch" can be used for all general purposes. In setting up a weaving room a large spool rack, a warping beam, a croisse, and at least one bobbin winder will be needed. I should think everything except the bobbin winder could be made in a manual training room if the school has a good manual training teacher. Otherwise the cost will be considerable as a large spool rack costs about $5.00 and the other two articles from $8.00 to $15.00 each. A bobbin winder can be bought from the Canadian Handicraft Guild, 2025 Peel Street, Montreal for approximately $2.00.

Some time ago we had to pay about 90¢ a pound for home spun yarn for blankets and one blanket weighing four pounds therefore cost $3.60 without taking into consideration the value of labour. The price of yarn of course increased since that date. It might be advisable for a new group to start with cotton warp for dish towelling etc. We use unbleached cotton warp size 2/8, which costs about 60¢ a pound in ten-pound lots.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Leon Savoie in connection with the vocational work at the Sandy Bay Indian residential school. He mentions two activities which the Department is inclined to assist at the present time:

1. For a small workshop -- hammer, saws, coping saw, planes, bench vise, chisels, bit brace etc. are needed.

2. For woodcraft -- the Hobbies Fretwork outfit and a pedal jigsaw for fretwork would be required.

Please let me have detailed information regarding the articles you require for the workshop and the woodcraft.

Mr. Savoie also suggests equipment for a shoemaker's shop. This machinery is expensive and the Department is not prepared to consider supplying it at the present time. As a matter of fact it is doubtful if it is worth while encouraging pupils to learn shoe repairing as it is unlikely that they would have an opportunity of earning their living by doing such work after they leave school. A more practical trade to encourage would be automechanics. It might be possible for you to obtain an old automobile engine without heavy expense and some preliminary training could be given.

Yours truly,

Dear Father Lemire:

I am in receipt of Inspector Hamilton's report regarding his inspection of the Sandy Bay Residential School. He reports very favourably on the work that is being done in the sewing room and the weaving room.

Dear Mr. R.A. Hoey,

Really I am pleased to see that you are greatly satisfied with what we are doing and trying to achieve with our Indian children specially mentioned in the sewing-room and in the weaving room. It is surely a great encouragement for me. I am trying also to have the older girls, even women from the Reserve to come and learn and work at weaving looms. It will be without any doubt a slow organization but hope to bring it to success. Later I will let you know if there are any results.

If it ever happens when coming into the West, you have a few days at your disposal, to come and visit our Sandy Bay School. I would be greatly pleased, and also it would stimulate our enthusiasm towards the educational welfare of our Indians.

You are inquiring about the qualifications of our Sister Supervisor of the boys. Well, the Sister has really no special qualification for manual training, but only a natural gift well developed in her. And, I believe, having tools, she could train the boys to a certain extent, but now at present, it is practically impossible having not even the most necessary ones.

According to your request you will find attached to this letter a list of tools that I have made with the Sister in Charge of the boys.

What I find also very important for the future of this Reserve is the compulsory education. It might be somehow difficult and hard to break in the parents towards it, but it has to come if we wish to build up any future hopes for this Reservation. I believe, forty children or more, of school-age, on the Reserve, to whom the parents are refusing education... and also what else... It is too bad! There is lot of room in School for them all, and more yet.

My little Scout Troop is still progressing, and my Indian boys are yet enthusiastic about it. It does them good! I am planning for the Girl Guides, but cannot get any answer from the headquater in Winnipeg...

Once more, many thanks for your kind letter and cooperation in the educational welfare of our dear Indians, and hope that I will give you always satisfaction in my educational work amongst Indians.

I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

Father J. Lemire, O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Sir:

Yours truly,

A.J. Doucet,

Dear Sir:

I have just returned from an extensive trip and found your letter on my desk.

I am instructing the Treasury Branch to send a cheque for $51.10. Apparently, they will not pay any transportation charges unless they have a Railway receipt. I am sorry that I am unable to do anything about this. I feel that it interferes with your system and makes it awkward for you. Whenever you are sending anything to an Indian school if you would instruct the Company to send you a copy of the receipt, we would then be able to accept this. Trusting you will find this satisfactory, I remain,

Yours truly,

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Ottawa, February 5, 1946.

Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I. Principal, Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, Marius, Manitoba.

Enclosed please find a suggestive plan for a general shop. A shop of this type must be on the ground floor. The ceiling should be eleven and one half feet high. If this shop is of fire proof construction it could be attached to the main building. If it is not to be built from fire proof material, then, it should be separated from the main building for obvious reasons. Needless to say, the dimensions of this building may be slightly increased or decreased in order to suit the space available.

This letter can not be considered an authorization to construct the shop. Please send us an estimated cost of material for this building. When we receive this estimate, we will be able to give this project further consideration.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

We still remember your many favors given to our school and wish to thank you again with all the gratitude that we can express. May you and your happy family feel as much happiness as you render others happy through your kind deeds.

Cher Mr Doucet,

Lors de votre passage à Sandy Bay, nous nous laissons
savoir que le Département des Affaires Indiennes encouragerait volon-
tier vos jeunes garçons au sortir de l'Ecole, en leur permettant de
suivre un cours de technique.

Nous aimerions que Christopher Beaulieu de Sandy Bay
Traité No 224, âgé de 16 ans, puisse suivre un cours de quelques mois
à l'Ecole Technique de Mr Vermander à Saint-Boniface.

Je voudrais également attirer votre attention sur deux
autres points. D'abord nous n'avons pas encore reçu les deux métiers
pour nos deux graduées de 1946: Martha Beaulieu et Esther Houle.

Vous le savez pour avoir visité nos écoles, que le
travail de pelure les patates prend un temps et un groupe d'enfants
assez considérables. Ce genre de travail offre à l'enfant très peu
de chance de formation et peut-même avoir le résultat funeste de le
dégoûter. Nous demandons donc par votre entremise une pelouse de
patates, au Département des Affaires Indiennes.

Nous signalerons également encore que nous aimerions
avoir quelque chose de définitif au sujet de la construction d'une
boutique pour "Vocational Training".

Un maître en menuiserie accepterait $1.25 de l'heure
et trois de nos post-gradués de la Réserve, travailleraient sous ses
ordres à .40 sous de l'heure. Il pense pouvoir accomplir le travail
dans 3 ou 4 semaines.

Nous vous réitérons nos remerciements pour l'intérêt
constant que vous nous témoignez. Espérant une réponse favorable sur
tous les items mentionnés sur cette lettre.

Votre,

P.J. Lambert, O.M.I. Principal

The handling of the 45" loom is similar to the 90" loom and requires the same manipulation. The Department, consequently, feels that all the educational value of the 90" loom is contained in the 45" one.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Ottawa, March 3rd, 1910.

Right Reverend Sir,

As Your Lordship is aware the improvement of Indian day school conditions has been for sometime receiving consideration and already marked improvement is noticeable in many instances. Some months ago particular attention was paid to the schools in the southern part of the North Saskatchewan Inspectorate, and, with a view to extending the work, the situation as existing on the more northern reserves has been looked into and reported upon, and the Department now wishes to try to effect an improvement at the Ahtahkakoop and Sturgeon Lake Schools.

Your Lordship will readily recognize as one of the first essentials to success the procuring of efficient and interested teachers, and to obtain and retain such the co-operation of the authorities of the church directly interested is much to be desired. This matter is, therefore, being brought direct to Your Lordship's attention with the hope that it will receive early consideration.

The Ahtahkakoop school is in charge of Mr. Louis Ahenakew, an Indian who attended Emmanuel College. The very poor enrolment and attendance at this school are evidences that there is something wrong in the management and the conclusion has been reached that the fault lies largely with the teacher. Mr. Ahenakew is reported to be

Right Rev. J. A. Newnham, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert, Sask.
lacking in scholarship and energy and to take no interest in his work. During the six years he has been in charge of this school he has evidenced no desire to improve himself intellectually and thus better fit himself for his duties. The first step, therefore, is to procure the services of a qualified teacher who will devote all his or her energies to the work. It is considered that a married teacher, male or female, would be most suitable and to a competent person the Department would pay a salary of $500.00 per annum. If a male teacher could be secured, whose wife would be able and willing to take up nursing and field matron work on the reserve, a larger salary would be allowed.

The above remarks apply in a large measure to conditions at the Sturgeon Lake school and Mr. Crain should be replaced by an efficient teacher, to whom the same salary as that at the Ahtahkakoop school will be paid.

These changes may be made after the summer holidays and Mr. Ahenakew and Mr. Crain should be notified at once that their services will not be required after June 30th, next, and in the mean time the names of successors may be submitted to the Department for consideration.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I am truly astonished at your letter. I can not pretend to understand the J.D. You propose great anxiety to have improved day-schools, with artificial teachers, gardening, nursing, etc. You bid me dismiss a faithful & earnest teacher because incompetent, I ask me to secure a competent one. Then you write I ask me to accept a woman who has no such pretensions & skill, but who has (I believe) a desire for the welfare of the Indians, but certainly not more so than has Louis Sherriner. Moreover she, however excellent herself, I admire her for what little I have heard of her, is the wife of a farm-instructor whom you have dismissed because he treats the Indians like dogs, or slaves. You say you have "excellent reports of her work" - if so, it only shows how little you can rely on the testimony of your local officials! I have nothing against her. I dare say her work would be excellent if she had a chance. But I understand that the school has been but little open, & hardly any scholars, because the Indians are so much away, so she has had no ground upon which to build up a good report.
With regard to this matter then, in answer to your question as to whether I will appoint Mr. M. Lord, they say:

1. Do you, or do you not, know of Mr. Lord's conduct? He is in many ways an active, diligent man, & has tried to make the Indians more diligent, etc. But he is rather crazy at times, or has a terrible temper. I have heard it very strongly prophesied that if you did not move him he would be attacked or assaulted by the Indians. He knocked me down with his gun not long ago, but the matter was hushed up. The Indians are terrified of him.

2. He might possibly succeed at Striped Lake; he will never do so at Sandy Lake, but might be marred or murdered!

3. The accuracy of the report from Mr. M. Lord's letters is more than doubtful—I don't care whether it was Christian or Brotherick who sent it—there has been no chance for him to prove his excellency.

4. The whole recommendation savours of an easy way for the I.D. to remove an official who has rendered his position impossible, & let him down easy by securing a position for himself. It in no way agrees with the desire of the I.D. for "improved day-schools."

Now, my dear Sir, I write plainly & confidentially. I write
in no hostility to the I.D., with all due respect for you, sir. But I do feel, as many of us feel, there is contention, that you do not hear the truth at all, that your local officials return partial reports, spare wrong-doers, give an unfair help to their friends, etc. I can only account for your action as to the Lord's wife by thinking that you have been misinformed.

It was just the same at the Pas when I reported against Mr. Fischer. The I.D. sent a investigator! The man was whitewashed & I was told I was mistaken. I am as sure of the truth of what I alleged as I am of my own name. And now Fischer is telling the Indians at the Pas, that we (the Church People) are blocking the way & preventing our building the promised Boarding School there! You know where the delay & hindrance comes. Mr. Fischer also told my missionary there that he had nothing against Mr. Lundie, & wished me to appoint him to Shoal Lake! I thought that Mr. Lundie question had been settled for good & all. If Fischer has nothing against him, I am sorry for Fischer's judgment.

I am very much taken up so much of your time, but I do not regret me and the above—

J.A. Saskatoon

Sir,

I have the honor to advise you that during the last two or three months, I have experienced great difficulty in securing adequate service for the transportation of the school children on both the Sandy Lake No.104 and the Sturgeon Lake No.101 reserves. The Indians inform me that the present allowance per day, viz: $1.50 hardly suffices to keep the team they have to work and further that the work necessitates the breaking up of practically the whole of the day. In many respects this is perfectly true, as it is often 11.50 am, before the transporters can return home to commence any other work they may contemplate doing. However, I have now come to a satisfactory arrangement with an Indian on each of the above mentioned reserves, whereby the trouble will be minimized to a great extent, if the Department can see their way to carry out the following suggestion. That is to furnish each of the following applicants with a team costing in the Neighbourhood of $400.00 each.

Viz: John Iman of the Sandy Lake reserve and Thos. Peter of the Sturgeon Lake reserve. Repayable in each case by half of the proceeds of their labor per month being returned to the Department on account of the purchase price, until such time as the debt is written off. This system, which has been in operation on the Mistawasis reserve has been very successful; and I really believe it is the only satisfactory way of solving the problem.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

There is more than one cause of a varied attitude at Indian School, and all Indians should be more lenient in their conduct.

Reasons for Poor Attendance

In the first place, there are many reasons for school age, who live so far from the school, that it is still much impossible for them to attend. A tendency is also in the case of girls.

Secondly, there is the influence of some parents regarding the education of their children. In this case, more often than not, they try to prevent their children from attending school because they require very little learning. They are less likely to work or earn any money, and have been known to become unemployed. The encouragement of women is not in the best interest.

Thirdly, children of both sexes are not to work too long to life, which they can get work, attend to cattle and horses. If this happens, and they are forced to work, it will be difficult for them to maintain their health.

They are not such a boy or girl as I said to assure me that he is working, and he must maintain his parents' hopes and dreams.

Then comes a case where a boy is content. Usually a pupil reaches 15 years of puberty, and goes back to school. At 12 or 13 years of age, she is called into work equivalent to a "young man" in England, and is in constant need for further attendance at school. I have recently heard some of my best pupils change his course, but it is uncertain. His age was lost by boys and girls who began to work at 15 years of age. It seems that the school has not been successful in maintaining its standards, and the school has lost its purpose.

It is time they knew something about the importance of education, and the value of their future school at USD period. It is time they knew...
The following is an extract from a Report dated in the year 1879 which indicates my views with regard to the importance of Indian schools.

"The school is, in fact, the first organization on the Reserve, the basis on which religion itself must build all refinements of thought or action; for its church can do but little if those whom she instructs cannot understand her teachings, while it is true enough that education is not, by any means, always a moral factor, yet it is none the less an established fact that ignorance, immorality & superstition go hand in hand. Cultivate the intellect & you open the door to which religion introduces a higher standard of morality & give it death blow to superstition. The Indian has capabilities & possibilities before him; but uneducated he finds much needs lie dormant, while his second are not realized. Would they may learn, whom the Lord of Science would have charged; but untaught they fail to execute the work they might otherwise have accomplished. The welfare of the Indian race depends upon its cultivation. Educate it & the old man of old will ultimately disappear & a new creation will take its place in the world's annals."

Sir:

I have your communication, relative to school matters generally, and with particular reference to the poor attendance at the Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School.

In reply I wish to assure you that the matter of school attendance on Indian reserves has given this Department cause for much thought and discussion from time to time, and a few years ago a clause with reference to compulsory education was introduced into the Indian Act. All children living within a reasonable distance of a day school can be forced to attend; but considerable tact has to be exercised by our agents, teachers and other representatives in this connection. If you find children who live close to the school are not attending regularly, and if your efforts with the parents are unavailing, the matter should be reported to the Indian agent.

The Department has discontinued the use of vans to haul children to school, and I regret to inform you that this method of securing a better attendance will not be resorted to at your school. The hot meal at noon, prizes for good attendance and interesting classroom and playground activities have all militated for larger classes.

With particular reference to the Ahtahkakoops School, may I suggest that you bend every energy toward awakening an interest in the younger pupils. There is, I know, an inclination to give instruction in more advanced work to the brighter pupils, but a teacher should not succumb to the temptation to offer Greek, Latin, Algebra, etc., to a boy or two, when a half dozen younger pupils are either learning to idle away their hours or are losing their interest.

If you wish to have some inexpensive primary materials, in addition to your present supply, or some athletic equipment for group games, I would be pleased if you will make a definite request. Our efforts to educate the Indian youth are abortive unless we can secure a good attendance. The problem is partly solved by making the school ground and the classroom more attractive to the child mind than the home and the bush.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir,

About a week ago, Mr. Ellis, principal of the Okotoks Industrial School, came here for the purpose of recruiting pupils for his school. He called upon me and assured me that he did not wish to remove any children who were attending my school, only those who living too far away could not attend. I found out, however, that such prior to his call, upon me he had asked one of my parents for his two children who were attending my school regularly, in two of my best pupils. The latter had refused, although Mr. Ellis would then confine his attention to those children remote from the school. Too late, however, I discovered that he had removed 8 of my pupils, regular attendants at my school. I had run a large school owing to previous deportations, and school has thus been reduced by half. I am certain Mr. Ellis has acted in a very unbecoming manner. Instead of coming to me with a request to be permitted to deport the children, he visited me again.

The average attendance for the December quarter was 7.84, a little over half of the enrolment. The Teacher Mr. H. Hutchinson is a man well advanced in years. He is hard of hearing, gruff and sharp in addressing the pupils; does not visit the homes, and I would say that his personality would not be conducive to making attendance at the school attractive for the Indian children. I feel it my duty to report that this man appears to have an unfortunate tendency towards antagonizing the people with whom he comes in contact, and his presence on the reserve is not conducive to promoting harmony on the reserve.

The present resident missionary the Rev. C. Morris I am informed has forwarded his resignation to be dealt with by the Bishop on his return from England. The attitude of Mr. Hutchinson has made life on the reserve unbearable for his wife and himself. His predecessor Rev. D.D. MacDonald resigned his charge for the same reason. They appear to have taken a high hand attitude with the Farm Instructors and have shown antagonism towards the Agent who will not visit them unless the exigencies of his business demands it.

The situation is wrong and intolerable, and I feel that the work on the reserve would not suffer by their removal.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Inspector of Indian Agencies

On April 6th, Nurse Colvin, Mr. Montgomery and myself visited Sandy Lake Day School, arriving there according to my watch at 9.18 a.m., en route on a general inspection of the different homes on the reserve.

On our way over we met Mr. Hutchinson at the residence gate according to his watch at 9.15 a.m. on his way over to the school. He did not speak to Nurse Colvin and passed the remark to me that we were early. I said, "No, you are late." Mr. Hutchinson shouted again that we were early, I said 'No' and informed him that 9 a.m. was the correct time for school to open, and in future school was to open at 9 a.m., Mr. Hutchinson shouted at the top of his voice, which could be heard at least a half mile away, and with the school children present playing on ice in front of the school, that 9.30 a.m. was the correct time for school to open, and for me to go and not interfere where I had no business to do so, that I was no gentleman and a snob. I informed Mr. Hutchinson that such was not the case, and that our conduct was all that could be desired. He then stated that he would fix me for it this time.

We then interviewed Mrs. Hutchinson, who was very nice to all, and made no mention of remarks made by Mr. Hutchinson. After Nurse Colvin consulted with Mrs. Hutchinson she went over to the school to examine the children. Mr. Hutchinson told the children to move down nearer the back of the school-room, young Tate was standing in the aisle waiting for Mr. Hutchinson to pass, as the boy was apparently in his way he grabbed and flung him into a seat. I might mention that I have had a great number of men to handle in my time, including all classes, and I have never had such impudence and disrespect to put up with than I have had to from Mr. Hutchinson.

I have discussed today with Reverend Mr. Ahenakew the school situation on the Ahtahkakoops Reserve. This school is in charge of Mr. E. B. Goodman, and I was delighted with the work that is being done.

The roll calls for 21 pupils, and 18 were present. The grades are as follows:

Grade I - 10
" II - 4

The children
The children were all neatly dressed, clean, and, without exception, all had their hair nicely combed.

The children appeared fairly well along in their work, and were not afraid to speak out. They appeared to understand their lessons, and were keen on making a good showing. The singing was excellent, and was enjoyed by the children, as well as those who listened.

The school is a log building, which, I understand, was erected in the year 1900. It is in good repair, and accommodates nicely the children now on the roll.

A noon-day meal is prepared by Mrs. Goodman, the Field Matron, and is served in the children's dining room, which is a part of the teacher's residence. The meal consists of vegetable soup, biscuits and tea.

In addition to the children on the roll, there are about 20 more of school age who live too far away to attend. I am attaching a map which will show fairly accurately the distance the pupils now live away.

It would appear that hauling the children is out of the question, and that the only solution to this difficult problem would be to recruit from the outlying homes for the Church of England Boarding School. I understand most of these Indians belong to that denomination.

Dear Sir:

In 1932 I wrote to the Indian Department at Ottawa asking for a readjustment of my salary; my request was refused. I herein repeat my request for an increase of salary & state my case as follows:

I started teaching in the Fort à la Corne Days School in 1922 & my wife was appointed Field Matron that same year. In 1927 we were transferred to Sandy Lake Reserve, Carlton Agency. In 1928 the Dept. abolished the position of Field Matron & received a 10% cut. So that at the end of ten years work our income was reduced from $1500.00 per annum to $810.00 per annum.

My wife has continued to carry on her work regardless of salary & has saved the Dept. several hundreds of dollars. I have worked conscientiously & consistently & I have brought my school up to a standard of proficiency equal to any Sask. Provincial School, with an attendance of 38 pupils & a
average of $30 for the year. I like my work & am willing to stay at it indefinitely but at the same time I feel that I am entitled to consideration & fair treatment at Ottawa. I have a bigger school & more work than most other teachers & am receiving a smaller salary.

Newly appointed teachers are being paid more while I am allowed no credit for my length of service.

Sister teachers with smaller schools are being paid more. I am a married man & have children to keep & educate & start in life.

I was I believe the first Day School teacher in Saskatchewan to pull pupils through grade VIII into High School. This year I have all the grades except grade VIII. I have continued the mid-day meal without any assistance from the Deptt. for 3 years.

For information regarding myself, my work & my school I would refer you to
Gentlemen:

Mr. P.S. Davis, The Bishop of Saskatchewan, The Minister of Education, Mr. J.W. Estey, Regina, & my School Inspector Mr. Ferris of Shell Lake.

I mentioned this matter to Mr. Morrison some years ago & he told me to carry on my work to the best of my ability & the Dept. would see me fairly.

This letter is in no way a complaint neither is it an expression of dissatisfaction with my occupation but rather an appeal for consideration & fair treatment.

I like my work & am happy in it.

I trust that you will consider my case with sympathy & if possible grant my request.

I remain faithfully yours,

Ernest B. Goodman.

Dear Sir:

I was, this afternoon, talking to Mr. Christiansen about my work here & my troubles & he advised me to write you what I had been telling him. He assured me that my letter would not just make kindling at Ottawa.

I have been teaching in Indian Day Schools for 15½ years. I taught for 5½ years at Fort à la Corne & ten years in my present school, Ahishkakopé Day School.

When I came there the school was in a wretched condition with an average attendance of 6 & I had a lot of hostility to contend with. I worked hard & put my best into it & within two years I had brought the attendance up to 32 Treaty Indians & 6 Non-Treaty. The average for the quarter ending Dec. 31st 1928 (of Treaty Indian Pupils) was 24.0%. From that time until the present I have maintained a full school; having had the quarterly average attendance go above the 30 mark & I have had as many as 42 pupils attending.
I was, I believe, the first Day School teacher in Saskatchewan to put a pupil through Grade VIII into High School. That pupil, Lancelot Henderson, will attend the next session at Normal School in Saskatoon. Another ex-pupil of mine, Ida Vandal, was among the group of students chosen to go to the Coronation. Other ex-pupils of mine are also doing well.

I receive a salary of $900.00 per annum. During the past 15½ years I have never received an increase in salary. In fact, for a time my salary was cut 10%. I have on two occasions asked for an increase and have each time received a polite refusal.

I am a married man of 41 years of age with a family to educate & provide for. There are single women teachers with smaller schools, less achievement & not nearly the number of years service to their credit that I have, receiving larger salaries. It does not seem at all fair. Farm Instructors, Clerks & Agents all receive regular increases & are allowed to subscribe toward a pension for their old age.

I have to send my children to Prince Albert to school & with our own living expenses I cannot save anything.

Apart from my own activities, my wife has worked without stint for the Indians & thereby her nursing, saved the Indian Dept. many hundreds of dollars. When we first started in the work she was appointed Field Matron & received a salary of $600.00 per annum. On April 1st, 1932, her position
salary were abolished. Ever since then she has carried on her work without pay; I have never refused a call for help, or has often been away all night on a maternity case. Every time the doctor visits a case he receives $1.00 per visit, but whenever I drive my wife to nurse a case I have to dig into my own pocket to pay the expense of gas & oil.

Since Jan. 1st, 1936 the Dept. have paid my wife $10.00 per month for dispensing drugs.

Every day school is free my wife cooks a hot meal for the school children. She receives nothing for this work. For about 2 years the Indian Dept. refused to grant any material or money (except biscuits) for the midday meal. During that period we provided the midday meal out of our own pockets. With the exception of one month, when my wife was too ill to attend to it, the children never went without their hot midday meal. We have never received any compensation or even thanks from the Indian Dept.

Being an Indian Day School teacher seems to carry a stigma with it. I can obtain no promotion. I feel that I am a parish of the Indian Dept.; I am sorry if I sound bitter, but I sometimes find it difficult not to be.

Before I spoke with Mr. Christianson I had already written a request for an increase in salary to the local Indian Agent Mr. R.S. Davis; asking him to put my request before the Official of the Dept. at Ottawa; so if you hear my request
I am a returned soldier. I served as a Flight Lieutenant in the Royal Air Force.

If you can help me to improve my condition, I will be very grateful.

Yours truly,

Ernest B. Goodman.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 18 and also a report on the Ahtshkakoops Indian Day School, submitted to you by Inspector Ferris.

I note with interest the Inspector's suggestion, that it might be left to the discretion of the teacher as to when the long holiday should take place.

It is highly desirable that no misunderstanding should exist with respect to the conditions that prompted the Government to operate the schools on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis. The records here indicate that attendance at Indian day schools throughout the Dominion has never been wholly satisfactory during the month of September. This unsatisfactory condition appeared most acute on a number of the larger reserves, such as the Tyendinaga and Six Nations Reserves in Ontario and was due, no doubt, in part, to the desire on the part of the Indians to have the older boys and girls engage in farm work - berry-picking, potato picking, etc. When the matter came up for discussion, the officials felt that the Government could scarcely afford to keep schools open and in operation with the attendance out of all proportion to the actual enrolment. For this reason and in an attempt to conserve public funds, therefore, it was decided to operate our schools for 9 months during the academic year. I note, however, from inspectors' reports, that almost every month in the school year has been suggested as the month during which certain schools should be kept closed. June has been suggested because certain Indian bands are anxious to get away from the reserve on hunting or fishing excursions -

excursions at this time. January has been suggested because of the severe weather usually prevalent in that month. December has been suggested from the standpoint of the convenience of the teachers, many of whom are anxious to get home early for the Christmas holidays. You can readily understand, therefore, the utter confusion that will result if we attempt to comply with these suggestions.

It should be pointed out also that an attempt is made to have our school supplies reach the schools on or about the actual opening date. This year we have failed in this respect because of the difficulty the Stationery Office has experienced in securing certain supplies. However, if certain schools open in September, having been closed in June, and others open in October, we shall require a special official here to keep the Treasury officials and the Stationery Office constantly notified of these changes. I am of the opinion, therefore, that unless local conditions are very exceptional, our schools should open on October first of each year and close on June 30.

The days in which we are living are, as you know, extremely critical, and it is our hope that we shall be able to secure the closest possible cooperation of our teachers and agents in carrying out regulations, the necessity for which may not always appear self-evident to the officials in the field.

Dear Sir;

Some eighteen years ago I went to the Orpheum Theatre in Prince Albert, Sask., to hear you address a public meeting. I was about sixteen at the time; the impression you left on my young mind has persisted through the years enabling me to feel confident that my letter will at least fall on responsive and sympathetic ears.

It is 5 months since I took charge of this school. My impressions on the evening of my first day here were typical of the general attitude towards the Indian problem. Wherever I have discussed the Indian and his education, and I have discussed it with everything from an Indian Agent, to three or four members of the Saskatchewan Legislature, I have run into the same feeling of resignation, the same feeling of hopelessness, and helplessness in the face of Indian lethargy, laziness and indifference. That is apparently a true picture of the average adult Indian. That is not true of the average 6 year old. They are as quick as keen, as energetic, and as intelligent as any children I have ever taught, and I have had eight years of teaching outside of Indian schools. I have been through the mill of rural schools with the usual Grade 1 to 11 business, and I have taught in town schools as well.

From what I have seen and experienced in the short time I have been here has convinced me that sympathetic, but adequately trained teachers, could and would raise a very high percentage of the Indian children to a spiritual, cultural and economic level, comparing favorably to the society of the outside world.

There is however a fly in the ointment. First and last, these children should be fed. They quite definitely are not getting enough to eat, either at home, or through the facilities of the school lunch.

I do not believe that the standard of teaching is high enough either. I do not believe that my own technical ability is sufficient to get the best out of these children. I intend to remedy the latter situation as quickly as possible. The results I have obtained since coming here give me the confidence and the courage to fight for these children, and fight hard. I am not particularly religious in the usual sense of the term, but after coming here and learning to know a little bit about some of these children, and after learning to love a few of the little rascals, I'll never know spiritual peace again until I have done all that is in my power to see that they get a square deal from the powers that be.

As I see my work here; it is simply this, I am working for these children, and no-one else. My duty is towards the children rather than towards the writers of my cheque. I have a strong feeling that you will help me, so long as I help these children. These children need food, and given food and well trained and sympathetic teachers, they can
and will become independent of further help.

Of course, speaking for the children of this particular school. I do not presume to prescribe a blanket remedy for the whole problem of Indian education.

I notice that I have used the word "sympathetic" with regards to teachers, twice. Possibly I had better define it as I meant it.

I mean a teacher who likes children, any children, and who really wants to help them. To put it another way. If this school was built to enable me, or someone else, to make a comfortable living here, then it were better that it burn down, or that it had never been built. Far too many of these Indians have nothing but distrust and hatred for their white masters. Masters we are, dictators if we like to be honest with ourselves. They do not trust us, they do not like us, they hate some of us; and they believe none of us, when we try to tell them that we have their interests at heart. I do not believe that it is the Indians fault that such is the case. I don't believe that it is the Norwegians fault that they don't like or trust Hitler, who, in his own words, is there only to protect them from aggression. We seem to be here to protect the Indian from the impact of the white man's way of life. We certainly were not invited to do so. I feel that the responsibility is entirely ours. That if we fail it is our fault. Either we have used the wrong methods or we have used the wrong people to put the methods into operation.

These people are worth all my efforts. I have promised them and I have promised myself, that I will always be ready to help them, even though it may at times get me in wrong all around.

My real purpose in writing this letter is to try and contact someone in authority who will at least consider my ideas. I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Davis the Indian Agent at Leask, and to the Bishop of Saskatchewan. I do not want anyone to get the idea that I am trying anything so stupid as, to pull a fast one.

Trusting that you are as greatly concerned as I am,

I beg to remain

Yours obediently

Walter L. Bigg (teacher)

Dear Mr. Bigg:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 6th instant, in which you discuss in a very interesting and arresting way the existing conditions at the Ahtahkakoops School and on the Ahtahkakoops Indian Reserve.

It was to me somewhat flattering to note that you remembered an address I had delivered at Prince Albert about 15 years ago. If I remember correctly, I was accompanied on that occasion by Mr. Andrew Knox, and I have still very pleasant memories of the large and attentive audience.

I am particularly pleased that you brought to my personal attention certain conditions that are confronting you, and I am glad also that you are sending a copy of this letter to Indian Agent Davis and to His Lordship the Anglican Bishop of Saskatchewan.

I cannot of course agree with all the conclusions you have reached in respect to the Indians, the progress they have made and are likely to make and the attitude of the Government to our native people. In view of your earnestness and transparent sincerity, I am anxious that you should not fall into the fallacy of reasoning from the particular to the general. We should not, for example when we meet a bad man, arrive at the conclusion that all men are bad; nor should we conclude, when we come in contact with a backward, dissatisfied group of Indians, that all Indians are backward and dissatisfied.

It was admitted at a Seminar Conference, organized by the Universities of Toronto and Yale and held at Toronto three years ago, that the Indians of Canada had perhaps made greater progress than any other primitive people of whom the delegates in attendance had knowledge. We had at that conference representatives from the continent of North America and Professor Loram, who was for a great many years adviser on native peoples to the government of South Africa.

You will be interested to learn that I was engaged in conversation with the member of Parliament for Brant when your letter reached my desk. Just as I opened it this member was informing me that the more he

Mr. Walter L. Bigg,
Teacher,
Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School,
Mont Nebo, Sask.
came in contact with the Indians of the Six Nations Reserve at Brantford the more he became impressed by their loyalty to the Crown and their devotion to democratic institutions. This group of Indians have already contributed this year $1,000 from their own funds to the work of the Red Cross. May I be permitted to submit another illustration extracted from the thousands that reach us almost monthly. The Indians in the Kenora Agency were this year particularly anxious to secure flags (Union Jacks) that these might be placed on their tents and tepees at treaty payment time as an indication of their loyalty to the Crown, and I might go on, but I feel this is not necessary.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, a copy of my report for the month of November, prepared by me for the Director of this Branch. I should add that the excerpts contained in this report were not selected but taken at random from the reports that had reached the Department about that time. These reports, of course, refer particularly to British Columbia. In this province, I am inclined to think that our Indian schools are perhaps as good as, or indeed one might say a little better than, any other schools operated anywhere in Canada.

I cannot persuade myself that we can do much to help Indians by "doing something for them". Our success will be determined largely by our ability to encourage them to do something for themselves. If I have any criticism to offer of the Government's Indian policy in Canada, I would say that when times were good and money was plentiful they appeared to have done too much for the Indians and failed to encourage these people to do something for themselves.

You, of course, are confronted with certain practical problems from day to day, and you are interested only - and rightly so - in ways and means whereby you can assist the pupils committed to your care. If I were in charge of an Indian day school I would attempt to teach the Indians how to look after their bodies and use their hands. This means a program balanced between academic and vocational instruction. Where a program of this character has been adopted the progress, as you will note from the reports, has been truly phenomenal.

I note with interest your reference to the fact that Indians should be fed. This is a task that should be undertaken by the Indians themselves, under the direction and guidance of the Indian agent. If the resources on the reserve lands, wood supply, water, etc., are at all adequate, it should be comparatively easy for even a group of Indians to become self-sustaining. In certain sections of northern Canada I have been encouraging the Indians to destroy all dogs other than those necessary
for transportation and to keep goats. Five goats, I have learned, consume less feed than one cow. The milk supply of these animals is nutritious and beneficial. The goat, by the way, is one of the few animals not subject to tuberculosis.

It is exceedingly difficult, of course, to send forward advice from this distance. Only a man reasonably familiar with local conditions can work out a satisfactory program. It is my hope, however, that you will have an opportunity to discuss your program very fully with the Indian agent and that your joint efforts will contribute substantially to the progress of the Indians on the reserve.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Will you please excuse me for my apparent neglect in not answering your letter dated September 9 regarding Mr. Bigg and his appointment to Ahtahkakoops School. My reason for delaying is that I have been away from Prince Albert for the last five weeks, spending the time in Eastern Canada doing deputation work on behalf of the missionary work in Western Canada.

I am quite surprised regarding your suggestion that we transfer Mr. and Mrs. Rigg to some other Indian School. I fully appreciate the fact regarding the wife being recommended as a qualified nurse. At the time of my appointment that was my definite understanding and I cannot understand where the mistake was made. Anyway, even if she were a trained nurse, I doubt if she could spend much time on the Reserve simply because she has young children who would demand practically all her spare time.

I wonder, Mr. Hoey, if you could give me some time to look around regarding this matter. It is my understanding from a previous letter of yours that teachers should not be asked to be transferred during holidays. Moreover, the difficulties of transferring a man at this time of year from one Indian School to another, as you can well understand, are considerable.

From what I have heard from the Inspector, Mr. Bigg

Dear Sir,

Being accepted to teach the Indian Day school here, I arrived Sept. 29th. The trip from Winnipeg, Sask., entailed considerable expense, having to bring furniture.

Although I have kept school going, I find I shall be unable to carry on. The whole proposition is too much. Up to now I have not seen the Agent, although I have written him. The water does not come up in the taps and there are no utensils for giving the children their noon day meal.
All this is much too much to expect of anyone, let alone a woman of 54 years.

I herewith beg of you to pay my expenses and transportation back to Winnipeg and let someone stronger have the position.

Dear Miss Ratz:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant, in which you discuss the conditions confronting you when you arrived at the Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School.

It is just possible that these conditions, in part at least, may be due to the transfer of Indian Agent Davis from the Carlton agency to the Touchwood agency. This transfer took place a few weeks ago. This will explain why you have not received a reply to the letters written by you to the agent. There is, however, a clerk in charge of the agency at the present time and it is my intention to communicate with him today. I am asking him, if it is at all convenient, to visit this school and do everything humanly possible to make conditions as comfortable for you as they can possibly be made.

You are aware, no doubt, that this school has been for years in charge of a married teacher and his wife, and I am not at all sure that it was wise to send a single teacher to take charge of the school. However, this is a matter over which the Department has very little control, and I feel confident that the Bishop did all he possibly could to secure a suitable teacher.

If there are senior pupils at the school, these pupils should be taught, as part of their regular educational program, to keep the classroom clean and in good order. If there are heavy tasks, such as the scrubbing of the floor and attending firesides, these should be undertaken by the caretaker. If there is a shortage of utensils necessary to supply a noonday lunch, these should be immediately purchased. I am asking the clerk to deal with these matters immediately.

It is scarcely necessary to add that these are critical days in which we are living and days that demand a large measure of self-sacrifice and devotion on the part of all of us. It is my hope that you will be able to see your way clear to remain at Ahtahkakoops for the present academic year at least. If, however, you feel that you cannot do this, you should communicate with the Bishop at once, asking him for a transfer.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Sir:

This morning I was advised that she had left the school and returned to Wimmer, Sask., with her brother who had come to take her home.

She seemed to have been upset over the water system and keeping up the pressure in the taps, this was caused by the pumping of straight water and not allowing air to be pumped with it.

I visited the school shortly before leaving for Punnichy and the school was fairly clean, the only thing was that the ashes had not been cleaned out of the furnace which was only a few minutes job.

Miss Ratz as you are aware was quite an elderly lady and naturally a little fussy.

I would recommend that the next teacher when appointed be a married man, as it is very unsatisfactory to have a single person in a school of this size. Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Day Schools and Superannuation Fund.

Owing to the present scarcity of teachers, I am experiencing great difficulty in finding teachers for the Indian Day Schools.

We had six vacancies to fill in this Diocese after the summer vacation; and five new teachers started to work in these schools on October 1st. One was Miss E.M. Ratz who went to Sandy Lake Reserve School. She had been paying into the Saskatchewan Superannuation Fund for 25 years; and when she found that teaching an Indian Day School would not enable her to continue the benefits of that Fund, she left on short notice. The school is consequently now vacant.

Mr. P. Farebrother is teaching at Big River Reserve, and he is in a similar difficulty. He has been paying into the Fund for 20 years, and if he cannot continue on this Fund by teaching this school, he wants to leave at Christmas.

I have always tried to nominate to the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa qualified and experienced teachers; and it is disappointing to have to lose them because they cannot continue on the Superannuation Fund when teaching in Indian Schools.

The teachers are qualified Saskatchewan teachers, and the schools are inspected by the Superintendents of your Department; and I should like to ask if arrangements could not be made between your Department and the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa, whereby teachers be allowed to continue on the Saskatchewan Superannuation Fund when teaching Indian Day Schools.
This matter is very important at the present time, when most of the younger male teachers have enlisted in H.M. Forces; and we have of necessity to employ older teachers, and it seems most unfair that they should have to relinquish their superannuation benefits after contributing to the Fund for many years.

Hoping that something can be done to remove this difficulty,

I am, Sir,

Yours faithfully,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of your letter of December 21st notifying me of the resignation of Mr. J. N. Ross, teacher of Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School in this diocese. I am so sorry that Mr. Ross feels compelled to send in his resignation but I can, of course, quite see his line of argument. I have written on previous occasions to the Minister of Education in the Provincial government here regarding this peculiar ruling in the Saskatchewan Teacher's Superannuation Act, but apparently nothing can be done at present. Nevertheless, I am hoping for this matter to be settled in favor of teachers in Indian Day Schools. From what I can gather it is the teachers themselves who hold fast to this regulation.

I will do my best to nominate a successor to Mr. Ross as soon as possible. I have already inserted an advertisement in the Saskatoon paper and I shall also try every other source of supply. I do hope it may be possible to nominate somebody in the near future.

Wishing you the compliments of the season, I am,

EXTRACT from Inspector's Report on the Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School, dated 6 December, 1945.

The effect of the family allowance on school attendance has been very marked. The present accommodations are taxed to capacity and yet there are twenty or more children on the reserve who cannot attend because of lack of room. As it is the teacher's time is very largely taken up with the very large Grade I class and the higher grades receive less attention possibly than they should. A second classroom would seem to be needed urgently.

I was pleased with the cleanliness and general well being of the children. They were well behaved, happy and certainly industrious as the children of the average white school. This speaks well for the teacher.

Dear Doctor,

Enclosed find two nominal rolls of schools completed this week. First Ahtahkakoops School, Sandy Lake. There are 42 pupils on the roll of this school, 39 were examined, 3 were not attending school, 3 were free of dental defects, I was not treated, being absent from school. 17 adults received treatment.

The pupils of this school are clean and with a few exceptions appear to be quite healthy. No noon day lunch is served. The children bring their own lunch and must remain at school for lunch. I was informed that hot cocoa and vitamin biscuits are served during the cold weather. This is the most efficiently run school that I have been in so far. I completed this school on Tuesday, November 2nd. Mr. Dowsdell, the Farm Instructor, moved me to Mistawasis School, Wednesday morning. I set up equipment in the Agency Office and stayed with Mr. Bell, Farm Instructor. There are only 16 pupils on the roll of this school. 13 were examined, 3 were free of Dental defects - 2 were not attending school, 1 (Matilda Whitefish) was not at school. I examined this girl at the Big River Anglican School but did not do any treatment for her as she was absent from school.

This was the least efficiently run school that I have been at - the pupils come and go as they wish and I was informed that the only reason the pupils attended at all was that Rev. Moore provided a good lunch at his own expense.

Oral hygiene and tooth brushes are unknown at any of the schools. I discussed this with the teachers and they are willing to have a tooth brush labelled for each pupil and left at the school, where they will supervise cleaning of teeth once a day. I believe that this would be the only practical method to adopt. It would be useless to give out tooth brushes for the pupils to take home.

Sorry that I did not include these observations in my monthly report. Will do so in future.

No arrangements have been made where I am to go next week. The equipment is here. I intend calling you today. It snowed one day this week and while the weather is fine again, we cannot expect much more of it. I am getting a bit fed up with doing these day schools under present conditions of transport and making arrangements with the schools. The latter I have to do myself after arrival at the school.

Sincerely,

O. G. Shepherd.

Re: Sandy Lake Indian Day School

Expenditure - $25,000.00

The above estimate covers anticipated costs of erecting a new two room day school and converting present combined class room and teacher's residence into suitable living quarters to accommodate two teachers.

The following shows the number of children on Sandy Lake Indian Reserve:

School Age - 72 Under School Age - 98

Our problem here is to provide class room accommodations to accommodate children of school age and also with a view towards future years.

At present a class room is contained in combined teacher's residence and class room, suitable to accommodate 30 pupils. In addition we have opened a class room in old Parish Hall, property of Anglican Mission, this particular building is old and not in a very good state of repair and lacks accommodation for the additional teacher.

I recommend that consideration be given to the erection of a two class room school building and convert the present combined class room and teacher's residence into two suites to accommodate and provide living quarters for the two teachers and their families.

Alternate proposal would be to move the present day school in use on Mistawasis Indian Reserve (When class room on Mistawasis Indian Reserve is installed in former Carlton Indian Agency Office) to Sandy Lake Indian Reserve a distance of approximately 20 miles, retain the present combined teachers' residence and class room on Sandy Lake as is, and erect a new teacher's residence.

The class room building now in use on Mistawasis Indian Reserve would require a substantial sum to move, i.e., new basement, rebuilding chimney and moving and re-installing furnace or possibly installation of a new furnace and possibly after going to the expense of moving we would find in a few years time that two day schools might be required on Mistawasis Indian Reserve. I therefore do not recommend moving the school class room from Mistawasis Indian Reserve to Sandy Lake Indian Reserve.
In the event of approval being given for the erection of a two room school building on the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve a substantial saving in costs of materials could be made by authorizing this office to have saw logs cut during the winter of 1949-50 by the members of Sandy Lake Band. Logs to be sawn into lumber to be used in erection of the two room class room building. All materials for the erection of the building could be secured from this source at a cost not to exceed $50.00 per M (Doors, windows, cement, flooring, shingles, wall board, nails, paint, etc., excepted). Materials from saw logs secured from timber available on the Reserve would cover dimensions boards, shiplap and siding, only.

I recommend that the expenditure be approved as it is necessary to provide the facilities for education of the children of Sandy Lake Band.

H. J. McLeod

Enclosed herewith please find Survey of Potential School Population of Ahtahkakoops Band #104 occupying the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve.

At the present we are operating two class rooms on the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve. One contained in a building designed for class room and teachers residence, the other class room is contained in a very old building formerly used for many years as a Parish Hall.

The Indian settlement on the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve is now centered in the area adjacent to our present school building site which borders on the south shore of a large lake contained within this particular Indian Reserve. I, therefore recommend that a new two room class room be erected on the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve and our present large combined teachers residence be repaired and converted into suitable living quarters to accommodate two teachers and their families.

You will note that the potential school population of Ahtahkakoops Band is fairly large and no doubt in a few more years we will find that a two room school building will not prove sufficient therefore we will be confronted with the problem of erecting additional class room facilities. When we find that additional class room space is required consideration will be given to placing a new building at a separate location and located in such a manner on the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve to accommodate any future Indian settlement that may take place away from our present school location.

I recommend that approval be given for the erection of a two room school building on the Sandy Lake Indian Reserve.

N. J. McLeod
