ANNAKAKOGE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

We have included in our Estimates the following sums for the provision of adequate school facilities on this reserve:

Two-room School ............. $30,000.00
Addition to Teachorage ...... 5,000.00

I believe that this should provide adequate facilities for both teachers and pupils.

In following your recommendations, it is our plan to provide a two-room school, without teachorage. The conversion of the present school into two teachers' suites should provide adequate space for the teaching staff.

Our experience in moving old school buildings has not been very satisfactory and we agree that it would be unwise to move the classroom building now in use on the Mistassini Reserve.

New standard plans are in the course of preparation for a two-room school and there should be no difficulty in advertising for tenders, etc., for its erection. Ottawa, February 12, 1924.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to the payment of your salary as teacher of the Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the school year begins on September 1st and ends June 30th, and, in an effort to make the Department's position clear to you, I wish to review the salary payments for the past two academic years:

| Academic Year 1921-22 | Academic Year 1922-23 |
|-----------------------|-----------------------|
| September quarter     | September quarter     |
| $150                  | $150                  |
| December              | December              |
| $150                  | $150                  |
| March                 | March                 |
| $150                  | $150                  |
| June                  | June                  |
| $150                  | $150                  |

Total ........... $600. Total ........... $600.

As there are ten teaching months in the school year, namely, one month in the September quarter and three months in each of the other three quarters, the Department decided to pay salary from September 1, 1923, as follows: 1/10 for the September quarter and 3/10 for each of the other three quarters. Therefore, if you remain in charge and the school is open for the full term, the salary payments for the academic year 1923-24 will be as follows:

| September quarter | $60. |
|-------------------|------|
| December          | $180.|
| March             | $180.|
| June              | $180.|

As you have been paid your salary for the September and December quarters there is no balance of salary due you up to December 31, 1923.

Your obedient servant,

H. Hutchinson, Esq.,
Mount Nebe,
SASK.

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have discussed today with Reverend Mr. Ahenskew the school situation on the Ahtahkakoops Reserve. He informs me that these Indians are very progressive now and that better school services should be provided as soon as possible. He believes that the solution is a new school building with accommodation for 40 pupils. Of course, it should be built on the reserve, near the teacher's residence, which is in good condition. Unfortunately, the new school could not be placed midway between the present buildings, as there is a gully there, and it should not be placed near the old classroom because it is on a mission lot.

Of course, two vans would be necessary to draw the children to school, as the Indians do not reside in one group.

Nov. 26th 1930

T.R. Ferrier Esq.
Superintendent of Indian Education

Dear Sir:

Ever since I came here over 3 years ago, we, that is the Indians & I, have been pleading & petitioning for new & better educational facilities on this reservation but we seem to get nowhere. I am writing to ask you for your assistance in our behalf.

The Indians are very sincere in their request & if it were granted, I know would do all in their power to make it a
losing success. Do you know they have asked for two vans to convey their children to a new school building. The present building is 30 years old. The band has progressed tremendously since the school was built - farming is being carried on in a large scale, so that those on outlying farms are unable to send their children to school. They do not wish to send them away to boarding school. It is a fact that our best & most progressive farmers are all ex day-school pupils. They possess that spirit I have never met with before in my experience among Indians i.e., "Esprit de Corps", & it would be a shame to let it die for want of
sympathy & material support.

I take it that the chief function of the Department is to assist & educate the Indians to a better way of life. These people are making tremendous efforts in that direction on their own & are most worthy of encouragement. They are just as enthusiastic & anxious over the farm school project as they were when they started 3 years ago in spite of all the negotiations & disappointments with which they have met.

You have, I believe, all the details & figures regarding this matter to hand, so there is no need for me to go into that
I trust that our request may meet with your sympathy & approval.

I remain,

Yours Truly,

Ernest B. Goodman

Sandy Lake Reserve (Ahtahtakoops Day School)

I visited this school on February 20th and found 28 pupils present, 13 girls and 15 boys, out of an enrolment of 33. The pupils are graded from 1 to 6. I spent considerable time in this classroom, as I found the pupils very bright and very interesting. In their reading lessons they spoke up quite audibly and I had no difficulty in hearing them. I consider they are making good progress in the different branches of their studies. The children sang several songs remarkably well.

The health has been good during the past winter and the pupils had a healthy and well nourished appearance. It was found that they were warmly clad. The conduct of the pupils when questioned was open and natural.

The school building is of logs, sided with lumber. It was built 35 years ago and is situated on Church property. I noticed the floor joists beginning to rot and no doubt in a short time will have to be renewed. The interior of the building, while found in a clean and tidy condition, requires redecorating. The teacher, Mr. Ernest Goodman, is doing excellent work and is one of the best Indian day school teachers we have in the service. He is interested in his work and not only is progress being shown in the classroom, but he takes an active interest in the children when at play. They are given regular physical drill in the winter, also skating and hockey, and in the summer swimming, soft-ball, and foot-ball, all of which the teacher supervises and enters into. It is very readily seen when entering the school that good feeling exists between the teacher and the pupils.
The Indians on the Reserve have supplied material for a mid-day meal. Some have supplied beef, others eggs and chickens. The teacher has supplied the vegetables from his own garden up to date. He also supplies milk, cocoa, and tea. Produce from the gardens unfortunately during the past season was reduced in yield by drought and early frost. While the teacher has been able to supply potatoes, onions, and carrots for the mid-day meal to date, his supply has become exhausted. I would recommend that the teacher be allowed to purchase vegetables for this purpose to carry them until the coming season's produce is available at a cost of $20.00. This, it is estimated, would meet the need.

There is no question as to the value of this mid-day bowl of soup, not only is its benefit reflected in the health of the children but in the attendance at the school.

Dear Sir:

The Department is considering in the Estimates for 1938-39, provision for a new one room Day School on the Ahtahkakoops Reserve.

In order that we may have full information, I would appreciate an early reply to the following questions:

(1) The approximate number of children for which provision should be made.

(2) Is the site available, or will it be necessary to purchase a site? In either event, you should state the size of the site you consider necessary and the general condition of the land, viz.: whether level or sloping. You should also mention the direction in which you consider the building should face.

(3) Will it be necessary to provide living quarters for the teacher, in connection with the School?

(4) Can drinking water be easily obtained on the site recommended by you?

Dear Sir:

As a counter proposal to building a new School on the Ahtahkakoops Reserve we would submit the following for your consideration.

The house the Teacher is now living in was built a number of years ago for a combined Boarding and Day School but was never used for this purpose though it was used for a hospital for a number of years. It consists of seven rooms and a large pantry downstairs and seven rooms and three large cupboards upstairs. It has three staircases, full sized basement with one furnace which is not large enough to keep the building warm. The building is forty four feet long and the main building is twenty two feet wide with the back part of the building being thirty six feet wide. It has nine foot ceilings.

If the partitions were taken out of the inside of the front of this building and the upstairs floor properly braced by a couple of stringers or iron rods, and the windows changed to the east side of the building, it would leave a class room twenty eight feet by twenty two while the back part of the house would remain untouched. This back portion contains three rooms of size large enough to accommodate a dining-room, kitchen and wash room.

The upstairs could be changed around as per the plans enclosed with adding on a balcony and staircases and would make a wonderful suite of rooms for the Teacher's Residence. It would be necessary to put in running water and sewerage as it would be unhandy living upstairs without these conveniences.

This building needs re-shingling and painting in any event and the upkeep of this building would be a saving and I consider the total cost would not exceed $2500.00. We would then have a first class school, ample play-grounds for the children, and a much better school than we could build for this money. In addition the Teacher would have comfortable quarters which he does not enjoy at present as it is impossible to keep the building warm.

I have talked this matter over with the Teacher and he considers that this would be a more feasible plan than building a new school and would be more satisfactory to him.

Yours truly,

I have in my school two bright youngsters Mary & Matilda Bird. Their Mother Mrs. George Bird is in very poor health. (Dr. Duncan is familiar with her case & I would refer you to him for particulars.) She is unable to maintain her home & care for her children properly. Both Mr. & Mrs. George Bird have told me that much against their wishes they will have to send their children away to a Residential School. I suggest that the Dept. pay a capable woman to look after this household so that the children may continue at this school. This would be cheaper than sending the children away to a Residential school. I have talked the matter over with the parents & they are quite agreeable.

I would further suggest that the amount paid to the woman be sufficiently worth while so that there could be no objection to boarding the
Massachusetts children during the week when the weather is too inclement for them to make the trip from the far end of the lake & back.

Brids have a good house with plenty of accommodation.

I have had a request from Andrew Blanchard for a door & 3 windows & hardware to enable him to build a house near the school so that he may start his children to school this fall.

I would be glad if you could take these matters up with the Dept. & let me know what they decide.

Yours Truly,

Edward B. Goodman.
Leask, Sask.,
July 22nd 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a letter received from Mr. E. B. Goodman, the Teacher at the Sandy Lake Indian Day School. The letter is self explanatory.

I would recommend that we pay a woman the amount of $15.00 a month to look after the Bird Children and also to care for the Masaskapuo Children when the weather is too severe for them to make the trip from home and return. The Masaskapuo children live over five miles from the school where the father has resided for a number of years.

I would also recommend that a small amount be allowed for provisions for the Masaskapuo children while they are staying at Geo. Bird's. This amount should not exceed fifty dollars for the school year.

The total cost of this plan would only be $200.00 while the cost, if these children were sent to a Boarding School would be over $300.00 for the Bird Children alone.

I would like to have an answer as soon as possible in order to make arrangements before the school term commences on Sept. lst.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach a Requisition from Ahtehkakoops Day School, Sandy Lake Reserve, Carlton Agency, for 24 pairs of skates and boots, 3 dozen spoons, and 12 large cups.

This is the first request I have received for supplying skates and boots, and no doubt it will be followed by other schools if granted in this case. At the same time it is my opinion that it would be of tremendous advantage not only for the health of the children, but also in their advancement.

On Mistawasis Reserve, where a few years ago the Indians were practically out of control and constantly consulting a lawyer, today they are working in close co-operation with the Department and making great headway. While in no way belittling the work of our Agent, Mr. Davis, who has done a great deal to bring about this condition, I feel that a great part of it is due to the fact that we have a good Community Hall located beside the lake. During the summer this Hall is used for social gatherings. In the winter, while it is used for the same purposes, they also have skating, hockey, and other ice sports, using the Hall for dressing and refreshments. This has brought the Band together, particularly the young people, and fostered a spirit of co-operation.

I feel the same effect would be obtained on all our Reserves if we could get our teachers or Farming Instructors to organize the young people into skating and other clubs, taking an active part in the direction of these clubs. The young people would in that way grow up in close touch with their officials, and we would obtain their co-operation, which is so badly needed.

Personally I would like to see these efforts supported by the Department. At the same time I realize the granting of these would be followed by others, and therefore I do not feel like making a recommendation, but would rather leave it to your judgment.

I am attaching Mr. Davis' and Mr. Goodman's letters covering this matter.

Yours truly,

Saskatchewan.

Re: Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School, Saskatchewan.

With reference to the above, I am forwarding herewith a copy of a memorandum from our Chief Engineer. The facts leading up to this point are as follows:

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 8th instant in connection with the above and notice that the only tender you received was for the amount of $4,674.40.

As you state in the third paragraph of your memorandum the Indian Agent estimated the cost of remodelling this building at $2,500.00. Dear Sir:

Re: Your letter of Sept. 11th, file 107-2-5.

I am instructing the Teachers of the Indian Day Schools of this Agency to only serve a light lunch to the pupils at mid-day instead of a hot meal as we have been doing in the past. Knowing conditions as I do on Indian Reserves, I feel that the children should have a good meal at noon as many of these children have to come four and five miles to attend school, in very cold weather. In many cases they are not any too well clothed and a good meal would certainly be appreciated by them, and would also be a wonderful help towards improving the health of these growing children.

I notice your remarks about increasing our relief allowance. I am proud of the fact that the Indians of this Agency have never been on relief, except the old people who receive rations under their treaty agreement. In most cases the most useless Indians have the most children and therefore, while the children are not actually undernourished they are not any too well fed. This condition exists, not only in this Agency, but in any Agency in western Canada. In my opinion it would not be a good policy to put these useless Indians on relief. However, if you wish to take this action I will make an application for some supplies for these families.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Indian Agent.

Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Agent, Leask, Sask.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 2nd instant, in which you submit an itemized list of the amounts necessary to provide noonday lunches at eight Indian day schools in your agency.

In this connection it is my understanding that vitamin biscuits have already been sent forward to these schools. You will be interested to learn that this year the Department purchased 25 tons of specially prepared vitamin biscuits at a cost of 22¢ per pound. These biscuits were manufactured, purchased by this Branch and distributed on the understanding that the vitamin content was such that the consumption of a biscuit or so per day was sufficient to provide the average pupil with the vitamins necessary for his growth and development, with perhaps the single exception of Vitamin D which is, as you know, secured from cod liver oil or substitutes of cod liver oil. In view of this fact is it necessary to provide elaborate noonday lunches at these schools? I have in mind at the moment not only the cost but the amount of time required in the preparation and serving of the meal and in washing up, with due regard for sanitation etc. I remember a few years ago when we decided to serve noonday lunches in the drought-stricken areas of Manitoba the time consumed in the preparation and serving of the lunches was such that the public school inspectors recommended their discontinuance. This letter is not written by way of criticism and is written by a man wholly unfamiliar with conditions on your reserves. I just want to be sure that our schools are
recognized not as restaurants but as educational institutions and to point out that the time during which the average Indian pupil attends school is decidedly limited. It is not my intention, however, to reduce, this year, the amounts you are requesting. I am asking, however, that you discuss this matter very fully with your teachers and perhaps with your medical health officers and with them work out a programme based on the nutritional and educational needs of the children in attendance at these schools.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Leask, Sask.

I attach requisition received from the teacher of the Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School.

Evidently the teacher is of the opinion that considerable work is required to repair both the school and the teacher's living quarters. It is not usual to place such a request on a Requisition for School Material form. Please let me have a report regarding the work that you consider is necessary and you should estimate the cost of material and labour. Encl.
Dear Sirs,

The board fence requisitioned for us much needed for the following reasons.

As can be seen from the diagram on the reverse side of this page we have no private yard for our children to play in. We have two children aged three and four.

The fence that is around the school now will not keep the children in and as there is thick bush on three sides of the school we are constantly worried for fear the children may get lost. The fact that the living quarters are on the second floor makes the watching of the children that much harder.

The proximity of the lake (Coye) is also much cause for worry on our part.

Hoping this requisition will receive a favourable reply, I remain,

Yours Truly,
Mrs. S. W. Hancock.

Dear Sir,

I have recently sent in a requisition for school material that is urgently needed. Unless this is received very soon I will be unable to carry on my work in a satisfactory manner. For example, I have on hand eleven pencils.

I have also sent in two requisitions during the past year. The first one on April 1st for school material of which I received about one quarter and the second in June for material to repair the living quarters and schools; have received none of the latter.

Some of the materials asked for in the April 1st requisition are urgently needed such as soap, towels, text books, etc. In fact, I have not asked for anything that is not needed badly.

Yours Truly,

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 24th ultimo in reference to Indian school matters in your Diocese.

In connection with the Sturgeon Lake school I beg to say that instructions have been given to have the school-house thoroughly repaired. These repairs call for an expenditure of close to $300.00 and, when completed, it is hoped that the building will be quite comfortable and much improved in appearance. As this expenditure is somewhat higher than was anticipated the matter of enlarging the teacher's residence will have to stand over till next year and in the meantime it is hoped that the present accommodation will suffice.

The contract for the erection of a teacher's residence and pupils' dining room on the John Smith's reserve was let sometime ago and the work is now under way. Any delay that occurred in proceeding with this work was unavoidable. The Department wished to erect a creditable building and had careful plans and specifications prepared. Following this tenders were called for, but all the details were attended to as promptly as was possible and the building should be ready for occupation by the Rev. Mr. Macdonald and his family early in the autumn.

Right Rev. J. A. Newman, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6280, file 600-8, part 1)
A change of teacher at the Ahtahkakoop school at an early date is no doubt most desirable, but, as in the case of the Sturgeon Lake school, repairs to the building in order to make it comfortable called for an outlay of $325.00 and funds are not available this year for the erection of a teacher's residence, owing to this fact it is deemed advisable to allow Mr. Ahonkew to remain in charge for at least another year.

It is noted that Your Lordship has in view a married man to take charge of the Sturgeon Lake school and the Department would like to know whether the present dwelling, which was erected by your church, will provide temporary accommodation. As Your Lordship has already been advised a salary of $600.00 will be paid a teacher and, if his wife is competent and willing to take up field mission work among the Indians on the reserve, an additional grant will be made for her services. In the absence of fuller information, however, a definite amount cannot at present be decided upon.

In reference to accommodation for teachers on these two reserves I may say that the Superintendent of Indian Education contemplates visiting the Carlton Agency in the near future and while there he will make special inquiry with a view to having the necessary work undertaken early next year.

Mr. Northwick, the Indian Agent, has been written to in regard to Mr. Oreno's complaint that he has not been furnished with necessary supplies during the last year and it is hoped that there will be no further difficulty in this respect.

In conclusion I beg to assure Your Lordship that the improvement of day school conditions in your Diocese is
correctly carried, but as it is quite a large undertaking and as similar improvements in any other districts have at the same time been considered progress must necessarily be comparatively slow. However, it is thought that a decided advance has been made during the past year and it is hoped that results next year will be even more satisfactory. In the meantime a communication from Your Lordship in reference to the qualifications of the teacher and his wife referred to above will be omitted.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.
Dear Sir,

I note with pleasure your desire to provide suitable accommodation for a married teacher on Satehakakop's Reserve. I have long desired a similar arrangement for some sort of accommodation for lodgers pupils when parents are away. In answer to your questions I would say:

1. A building on the plan of the Mrs. Smith's new school residence, with a small dormitory over the principal room might serve well for Satehakakop's.

2. I am inclined to advise an inside staircase only but for the pupils, a central aisle from this, separating the two dormitories; another door opening into this passage from a room in the house, which room might be occupied by the matron or nurse. This would still leave 3 bed-rooms for the teacher's family.

3. The dormitories should be well ventilated, almost open at each end.

4. As you ask me, I would say that Satehakakop's school accommodation requires almost (or quite) nothing, mean for the class rooms besides the building of teachers' house, pupils dining-room, etc. If this new scheme is successful there should be at least twice as many pupils as the present room will hold. It may be found necessary also to fetch the first-class pupils. There should be a married teacher swift, & also an extra teacher for the little ones.

Yours faithfully,

J. H. Saskatchewan

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Oliver.

The Department has in view the erection during the coming summer of residences for the teachers with dining-rooms and small dormitories attached on the Ahtahkakoops and Sturgeon Lake reserves, Carlton Agency. It is proposed to combine the best features of the plans followed last year in the residences erected on the John Smith's and Mistawasis reserves.

In view of the remoteness of these locations and the difficulty of getting tenders from contractors who reside in Prince Albert and the other towns at long distances from the reserves I am of opinion that it would be preferable to employ day labour in this work. Mr. Borthwick quotes an approximate price for the buildings, if erected by day labour, which is reasonable. Both the Indian Agent and the Architect who prepare the working plans will
will be held responsible for the character of the work.

I would, therefore, recommend that advantage be taken of Clause C, Section 36, Chapter 39 of the Act respecting the Public Works of Canada (R.S.'06), which provides that where the estimated cost of work is less than $5000.00 and it appears to the Minister that, in view of the nature of the work, it is not advisable to invite tenders, public tenders need not be called for.

The estimated cost of these buildings is $3,500.00 each.

May 23, 1911.

Sir,

Referring to your telegram of the 19th and to my reply of today, regarding the tender of Contractor Goodfellow for the construction of the proposed buildings in the Carlton Agency, I have the honour to state that Mr Goodfellow and his partner, in view of the fact that there is no scarcity of work within the city and only a limited number of contractors and workmen available, have evidently calculated from the first that they will not incur the risks and inconvenience attending work in the country except at a very safe figure. They consequently decline to further alter or modify their tender in any particular.

I went into the matter carefully with Mr Knox, who is of opinion that while building operations are somewhat more expensive this year than last yet the difference in the actual cost of material and labour is not greater than 10 to 15 per cent. There is no doubt, however, that over and above this actual increase in cost contractors are generally figuring on larger profits to themselves.

Mr Knox estimated when he prepared the plans for the teachers' dwellings that they could be built for $8500 each, and he is of this opinion still. He believes that it might be possible to secure competent foremen, one for each building, at about $6 per day. There are around Shellbrook and Marcelin a few skilled workmen, carpenters and plasterers, who are unable to tender on these buildings but who would take employment under a foreman on such work. Mr Borthwick
has mentioned some such men who are available and who, he thought, would be competent to act as foremen themselves. One whom he mentioned lives at Shellbrook and one at Marcelin, but I do not know them myself and cannot just now say anything further as to their qualifications.

I have also approached Mr Knox as to whether, in case it is decided by the Department to have the buildings constructed by day labour, he would undertake to superintend the work on any or all of them. Although already engaged for a considerable amount of work in the city yet he would undertake this work. He would prepare lists of material, showing the quantities and description of the same, for the guidance of the Agent in the ordering; or he would order the material himself if required to do so, and from such dealers as might be designated. I might say here that Mr Knox could be trusted to see that the Department got good value for all sums expended in this way.

Mr Knox has telephoned me to the effect that he thinks he will be able to suggest the names of some competent men to be employed as foreman, as he has had in his employ at one time or another many of the best workmen in this place. These men will not be getting more than $4.50 or at most $5 per day at present; but to leave their present employment and take work in the country, I am convinced from enquiries I have made that good men will require not less than $6 per day, and possibly as high as $6. Men living at Shellbrook or Marcelin could be had for lower pay.

For his work, as above stated and including the general direction and inspection of the work, Mr Knox would ask 5 per cent of the cost of the buildings, this covering also the preparations of the plans. He would also
expect actual travelling and incidental expenses.

By the method here outlined the buildings could probably be built at a considerably lower cost than on the tender already submitted; and under Mr Knox's direction an equally good job would be secured. By entrusting him also with the purchasing of material, arranging for the transportation of material, and engaging of workmen, he would have full responsibility for the completeness of the work, and the agent would be freed from the burden of these duties, which would be the heavier because of his want of intimate acquaintance with building operations.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

(Egd.) W.J. Chisholm

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,-

I have the honour to state that the Indians have been making requests for a small day or boarding school here. The following reasons are cited:

(1). Very young children should not be allowed to go to very large schools at some distance off and leave their family connections.

(2). Delicate children should remain at home until they are physically able to go.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit my report on school matters as requested.

Education.-There is not any school on the Assiniboine reserve. The children of school age are sent to Regina and Qu'Appelle Industrial schools.

These Indians are asking for a small Boarding school to be established on the reserve, as they are against sending their young children to either of these schools. They state that the young children become sick in these large institutions and are not noticed until they are very ill. The children are often too bashful to tell anyone they feel sick except their mothers. I know there is some truth in this, as a number of children have died at those schools or are sent home sick. Some have died after they came home, others have recovered.

We have at present about fourteen children who could attend a school on this reserve, but most of them are too young and delicate to insist on sending them to either of those large institutions for the reason I have stated regarding the parents' prejudices against the large schools.
They state that if they had a small Boarding school on the reserve they could see their children on Saturday and Sunday and would know if anything was wrong with them.

Of the fourteen children on this reserve eleven are supposed to be Presbyterians and three are supposed to be Roman Catholics.

I may say for your information that about fifteen years ago Professor Hart of Winnipeg arrived here to pick out a place to erect a mission for these Indians I assisted him to pick the place. The Mission branch of the Presbyterian church built a stone house.

Rev. E. McKenzie is the present missionary. He is at present teaching a few children. His wife has a sewing class twice a week for the girls, which I think is an excellent thing. They advise them on sanitary subjects and cooking. This couple have no family of their own and are doing all in their power to make these Indians followers of the cross. They also visit the sick, Mrs. McKenzie being a trained nurse.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I may say that the readers were received in good time and have used some of them already! The reader is the regular Alexandra in use in the province. The school has been open for one week from 9 a.m. till 4 p.m.; recess and noon as in regular school. The attendance average to date is 9.6. There has not been any difficulty with reference to dinner, as was predicted by outside parties. All that has been received 4 cts. of biscuit per day. There has not been any kick registered yet. Seventy five pounds of biscuits were received during the week. Four rear end seats were received during the week and are being set in place. Neither blinds, globe or plasticine have come yet. I should like to have the blinds soon as the light is hard on the eyes.

Sir:

The Day School was opened on the 4th of July. I have been doing all in my power to force the attendance. I have succeeded fairly well. The children are getting into the habit of attending school. Their progress at school work is somewhat handicapped by lack of English. Reading, arithmetic, and writing have been well cared for. In these the program of studies for Saskatchewan has been followed. Attention has been given to bodily drills and exercises.

Cleanliness has been looked after so far as it is possible in a day school. Further provision ought to be made for cleanliness. Ventilation of the school has been good. The health of the children in the majority of cases has been good. The attitude toward their work is favourable, that of the parents decidedly favourable.

The number on the roll is 21; the average attendance has been 13.75. The school itself is neat and clean. Proper put houses and play grounds have been provided.

The children have made good progress for the time. It must be remembered that the majority of them have never been in school before and it takes great patience and hard work to teach them.

Dear Sir:

Received today an official cheque, no. 1847, for $10.41, dated Dec. 10th— as the balance of my salary for the September quarter. That evidently means that the Department intends paying me at the rate of $550 per year. That is what I agreed on when I accepted the position as teacher here, but with the understanding that I was to have the privilege of teaching in a mission school. I understand, however, that it has
since been decided to make this wholly a Government school, and under the changed conditions, I see no reason why I should not receive a salary equal to that of the public school teachers in the West. Many rural districts pay $725 a year, some of them with an average attendance of only eight or ten pupils, while I have had here an average of about twenty this week. (The attendance has increased since the introduction of the mid-day meal about three weeks ago.) In many foreign settlements, where it is harder to secure teachers, the salaries are still higher.

To make a school like this a success, is a greater demand on one than the work in an ordinary public school—especially with children as yet undisciplined, and only six out of the twenty-four now enrolled able to understand English.

I was led to understand that when the change from a mission to a Government school took place, there would be a substantial increase in the salary. Kindly let me know what I am to expect, before the time to send in this quarter's returns.

I am, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Sir,

I have the honour to report a visit I made to the Assiniboine Day school.

There were nineteen children in school at the time of my visit. They were as usual quite as clean as you would find children at Industrial or Boarding schools. The class rooms was perfect in every respect.

My visit was not expected so there was no dress parade. The children have made wonderful progress in the classroom work. It is hard to believe that such advancement could take place in such a short time.

The gardening season is now on. Most of the children have individual plots and the garden is well prepared and nicely laid out. The school surroundings are perfect.

Last month there was an average attendance of 18, which is decidedly satisfactory. This Day school is without doubt a decided success and will remain so as long as the present teacher, Miss Lawrence, is in charge. She is thoroughly competent and takes more than an ordinary interest in her work.

The Presbytery also state quite frankly that it is going to be impossible to secure fully qualified teachers for the Indian Schools while the salary is below the average. Our District Superintendent reports that most of the teachers in the Province of Saskatchewan are now receiving about $75.00 per month. The salary paid at Hurricane Hills has been $60.00.

We will continue our search for a teacher, but we would like to have someone temporarily in charge.

He rang up to ask me if I had heard anything of a teacher yet, and I told him I had not. He himself has been doing his utmost to secure one, but up to date has been unsuccessful. He is of the opinion that we shall not be able to get a teacher for the same salary as was paid to the last one, viz., $720.00 a year, but thinks $850.00 would be the least anyone would accept. I agree with him on this point.

Dr. Strang spoke about having an assistant to help prepare the mid-day meal and I told him I did not consider this at all necessary, as this meal was a simple affair consisting of a biscuit and a cup of tea or bowl of soup. The kitchen is in the basement and the older pupils keep the fire going and it is a simple matter for two of the senior girls to prepare this meal and wash the dishes. It takes only about an hour each day and is good training for the girls.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that there is a matter in connection with the school at this Agency which is and will cause descension in time. It appears that the Presbyterian body are assuming and also preaches to the Indians here that the school is a Mission school and is connected with the Presbyterian church. The new teacher Miss MacTavish is labouring under the same impression. I have been informed by Mr. Inspector Graham that this school is an Indian Day school but must not be considered as connected with any certain denomination. I have always told the Indians this, but owing to the way the Presbyterian Missionary (Mrs. MacKenzie) lectures it makes the Indians doubtful respecting what I say in the matter. We have two factions (Roman Catholics and Presbyterians) on this Reserve. The children of both are attending this school and I am afraid if matters continue and this impression becomes established it is going to have a very bad effect on our school. Would you be good enough to inform me if this school is connected with the Presbyterian church or is it non-sectarian. Dear Sir:

We are experiencing a good deal of difficulty in securing a teacher for the Assiniboia Indian School, on account of the salary that is being offered. Apparently all the teachers in that vicinity teaching in the English schools are getting more money than has been paid the teacher at the Indian school. Dr. Strang, our District Superintendent, and Mr. McKechnie, the Inspector of schools for Saskatchewan, have been on the lookout for weeks. I have a wire from Dr. Strang this morning, which reads as follows:

"I can secure Florence Langton who possesses a second class professional certificate and ten years experience for $100 per calendar month. Will the Government pay this? I can secure a teacher with third class professional certificate for $90 per month. I have an offer from Etta Thompson who has a second class non-professional certificate, but has had no experience, for $75. Please telegraph instructions."

Before making a reply to Dr. Strang I would like to have your judgment in this matter. Dr. Strang does not intimate whether the teachers desiring $90 and $75 respectively want these amounts for the calendar year or for the ten teaching months, but I judge they want these amounts for the calendar months.

Hoping to hear from you by return mail,

Yours sincerely,

J.H.E.A.V.

There is a Day School situated in this Agency about a quarter of a mile from the Agency headquarters. The school is conducted by Miss Glover, whom I found to be very interested in her work, and I believe is quite a capable teacher. I, however, found the attendance at the school away below what it should be. There are 28 children on roll - 17 girls and 11 boys, who are entered in the following grades -

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 1     | 14     |
| 2     | 8      |
| 3     | 4      |
| 4     | 1      |
| 5     | 1      |

Taken for the last six months, the attendance in the fall was from 8 to 14 a month, in January it went down to 6.26, which shows that not one-quarter of the number of children were attending during January. As this was not a very satisfactory showing, I had a meeting of the parents, and discussed the school question with them, and assured them that this state of affairs could not continue, as unless the attendance was better than at present, the Department would probably be obliged to close the school, and in that event the children would have to be sent to a boarding school. On no Reserve have I ever found the Indians so averse to sending their children to boarding schools as they seem to be under the impression that it is practically the same to send their children there as to send them to their graves. They are, therefore, very anxious to keep the Day School going, and as seventy-five per cent of the parents are school graduates themselves, they believe in education. The low attendance at the school is not altogether the fault of the parents, although to a great extent it is; a number of the boys are sent to school every morning, but instead of going to school, they play around the Reserve, and about the time the other children are coming from school, they join in with them and go home. In some cases the Indians are really living too far from the school; those living on the south end of the Reserve are about six miles from school, and those living on the northeast portion of the Reserve are about seven miles from school, and several of the children have got to travel from three to five miles, and as a number of them are young, it is really too far to send them in cold weather. The Agent claims he has time and time visited the parents and talked to them and to the children about attending school, but without much results. I think, however, that my meeting with the Indians will stimulate their interest, as I made the situation very plain to them, and the second day I was on the Reserve, there was an attendance of 14 at the school, and on the third day there were 16, although both days were stormy.

Several of the Indians made the request that a conveyance be supplied from each end of the Reserve to take

- the children to -
the children to and from school, as was the custom a number of years ago. I advised them that the attendance so far did not warrant this expenditure, and as the winter was nearly over, and the summer coming on, this could not be considered at present. If the attendance is good during the next six months, it might be well to consider some kind of a conveyance to take the children to school. This, however, is only a suggestion.

The school itself is in good repair, and was clean and tidy. The teacher lives in a small residence, just back of the school.

Mr. Inspector Christianson, in a report dated February 27, 1922, states that Miss Glover, the Teacher at the Assiniboine Day School, is capable and interested in her work. 28 were enrolled and the average attendance for January was 6.26. The Inspector had a meeting of the parents and informed them that, if the school attendance did not improve, the Department would consider closing the day school and assign the children to residential schools. The parents seem to believe in education, but are adverse to sending their children to residential schools. The Inspector promised consideration to a conveyance to bring the children from the farther homes to the school next winter, if the attendance kept up at an encouraging rate for the coming summer and fall.

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo No.102-1-I, in connection with the attendance at the Assiniboine Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that from the time of Mr. Inspector Christianon's inspection last winter of this school, every effort has been made to endeavour to have the parents send their children to this school more regularly, and some of the worst delinquents have since been sent to Boarding Schools. In some cases it is not altogether the fault of the parents as they have sent their children from home to go to school but the children have not always put in an appearance.

For some years it has been a source of great dissatisfaction amongst the Indians that the school is situated where it is, and not in a more central location on the Reserve. According to the accompanying diagram it will be seen that most of the children who should now be attending this Day School have a long way to come, and this is an excuse for non-attendance which the Indians have put before me on several occasions.

It is extremely difficult in any case where the children are living with the uneducated Indians to get the parents to realize the importance of education and any excuse is put forward for their being absent.

With the younger generation where English is always spoken in the homes the situation would not present so many difficulties if the school was in a more central location; but where children have to go such a long distance especially in stormy or cold weather, there is a constant anxiety resting on the parents from the time the children leave home in the mornings until they arrive home again in the afternoon.

Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa
Another important factor and objection is that amongst some of the younger Indian parents who want their children to go to school; in order to insure regular attendance they are compelled to have them boarding with some of their older relations (generally uneducated and old time Indians) who live in closer proximity to the school. This means over crowding in the houses which is generally from the stand point of sanitation alone more of a detriment than a benefit.

There is no denying the fact that this Day School is not a success, and unless some means can be taken to take away the excuses and I may say in some cases valid reasons for non-attendance the probability of making it a success is very remote.

From the other view point, supposing the school was moved to a more central location the doubt arises of the difficulty in getting a teacher to go and live near the school and practically 3 miles by the road from the Agency. The teacher here has no means of transportation or of obtaining her supplies except when she goes into town or sends with some of the Agency people who are going to town; and would be isolated to a certain degree from white communication. I know that in certain isolated school districts in the foreign settlements around where the teacher has to live by him or herself at the school the Department of Education has to allow a very high rate of salary in order to get a suitable teacher to live under such conditions.

I understand that some years ago there was a system of having the children driven to and from school. Requests have been made to me from time to time by some of the Indians to have this started up again; but it was not a success then and had to be abandoned, and I feel sure it would not be any more of a success to-day than it was before.

In conclusion I beg to say I have endeavoured to explain to the Department as fully as possible the difficulties there are to contend with in connection with this school: and I would appreciate any suggestions the Department might offer as a means of overcoming our present troubles in this direction.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I got your letter a few days ago with a copy of a letter bearing date of November 24th, from J.D. McLean, Ottawa, advising you that the Indian Department is seriously considering the advisability of the early closing the Assiniboine Indian Day School and placing the children in residential school because of the irregular attendance. I at once advised Rev. Wm. Miller, the teacher missionary that we would visit the Reserve and consult the parents about this important matter. I also advised Mr. McDonald and he was willing to make the trip down. In reply Mr. Miller by phone advised me that owing to the deep snow and the cold weather that it would be impossible to get the parents to attend a meeting. I asked him to write me fully concerning this matter. I got his letter today. He says that the average attendance for October was 8.5, for November 9.6, for last week 9.2, for the week before 11.2 and for the week before that 13. He says the attendance is better in the winter than in the summer, except in extreme weather. He told the children that there was danger of the school being closed unless there was a better attendance. He also advised me that he would tell the parents. He says the parents would raise quite a howl if the school were closed. He says that there are only five children within three miles of school and that the rest are from three to six miles.

In 1913 the Indian Department provided transportation by bus to and from the school and dinner for the children. I am of opinion that this should be done again. The attendance of white children who had to come from three to six miles to school this weather would not likely be at all satisfactory. The transportation plan was discontinued when the war broke out and has not been resumed. I am of opinion that it should be. I hope that the Indian Department will not take any hasty action in this. I think that Presbytery will very strongly oppose closing the school. If a strong resolution from Presbytery and a petition from the parents of the children will be of any value, we shall be glad to get it for you.

I think the bus plan of getting the children to and from school should be urged upon the Indian Department. This would solve the difficulty.

I am,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the Assiniboine Day School, inspected January 17th, 1928.

The roll call here numbers 30 - 11 boys and 19 girls. Those present on the day of my visit numbered 18, and this number has not been exceeded except on one occasion when 19 were present. The average for the quarter ending December was 14.4, and that of September 13.6. The children are hauled to school, but even in spite of this, they remain home if the least excuse can be found.

The classroom has been nicely decorated since my last inspection, and is much brighter and more cheerful. I noticed a number of children had their coats in the classroom instead of hanging in the cloakroom. However, on examination, I found all the hooks but three either gone or broken. This certainly must be due to carelessness as the remaining hooks show that they were made of heavy material and would not break with ordinary jars.

- Grade 2 " 17 "

The work examined was only fair, and in view of the discipline, I doubt if very much progress is made. The children, when in class, stood in any manner and, if possible, leaned against the wall or lounged on the front seat. In fact, they hardly appeared to know what it meant to stand in a straight row.

Dinner is served in the basement, but it certainly did not present a very clean appearance. I believe it is difficult to keep this place in decent shape on account of the coal bin and furnace. The floor was quite dirty with coal dust and ashes. I found some dishes not put away and the dirty dish water was still in the dishpan on the stove. I realize that this is far from a satisfactory kitchen and dining room, and yet I believe it could be greatly improved if more strict supervision were maintained.

The cistern pump would not work, and I found about half the pipes leading from the furnace disconnected, either broke at the elbows or pulled apart. The check damper in the furnace is also apart and should be repaired. The Agent informed me that he had this furnace repaired some time ago, and apparently the present condition is due largely to the rough manner in which the children carry on. Some of the furnace pipes are badly dinged and bent and apparently have been hit by something. The basement wall was whitewashed at one time, but is now dirty. One or two coats of lime would brighten the place and give it a cleaner appearance.

The school has also been painted outside, and the work apparently well done. The fence was repaired and painted. However, I noticed one or two pickets...
pickets were already broken. Two swings were erected from which the children have derived a great deal of pleasure.

The wooden pump in the school yard I found frozen solid. The head was split and I have no doubt that the lower pieces are damaged if not destroyed. This certainly shows lack of interest and could have been avoided had anyone been interested enough to attend to the matter.

As mentioned in other reports, Mr. Millar has only one arm and can hardly be expected to do much repair, yet I do think he could exert himself more; at least the children could be made to use more care as regards government property, and continual repair should not be necessary.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith Mr. Hamilton's report on the Day School in the Assiniboine Agency and I regret that conditions are not a lot better than they are. With an enrolment of 30 children and an average attendance of 13.6 and 14.4 respectively for the quarters ending September and December there is something radically wrong and it seems to me that this is a field where we should send the children to Boarding School. As matters stand it just means that these children are receiving a very indifferent education and the Government is paying for it.

I may say that last year I visited this school and saw that the interior of the classroom had been sadly neglected and it was the duty of the teacher and the Agent to report on this matter before allowing it to get down to the condition in which I found it. The Inspector reports that the basement was not in good shape. INSPECTOR HAMILTON'S REPORT ON ASSINIBOINE DAY SCHOOL

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the Assiniboine Indian Day School, inspected on January 8th, 1932.

This school is in charge of Miss F. Hodgson and splendid results are being obtained.

The roll calls for 35 pupils and 32 were present. The average attendance for the three months of the last quarter being October 29.04; November 31.25; and December 30.56, and for the term 30.24.

The grades are arranged as follows:

- Grade 1 - 14
- Grade 2 - 7
- Grade 3 - 9
- Grade 4 - 6

These children speak out well, are attentive, and I found the exercise books tidy. Prior to the present teacher taking over this work, the children would not speak above a whisper and singing was entirely out of the question. They are now able to sing quite well and the selections are bright and entertaining.

A noonday meal is served in the basement of the school. The children do most of the work in regard to preparing the vegetables and the washing and cleaning up of the dishes. This is a splendid training for girls and they appear to take pride in doing well any duties assigned to them. The meal consists of soup made from beef, vegetables, rice and barley.

Dear Sir,

For the past twelve years I have been teaching in the Assiniboine Indian Day School. Last July I helped with the Indian exhibit at the Regina Exhibition and during that time had several talks with Inspector Christianson regarding the work of an Indian Day School teacher. We discussed the value and the possibility of holding a conference of Indian Day School teachers and Mr. Christianson suggested that I write to all the teachers in the province to get their opinion of such a conference and any
suggestions they might have to offer us to a time and place of meeting.

Some time ago I wrote to the twenty-two teachers and have had replies from seventeen of them. All expressed themselves as being very much in favor of a convention although several of them felt that the great distances and poor means of transportation would make it very difficult for them to attend. Some of them pledged themselves to be present if a conference could be arranged. Several mentioned matters they wished to have discussed—i.e., a course of studies especially for Indian Day Schools and superannuation for teachers.

An attempt has been made by a few of our teachers to have all Indian Day School teachers of this province included in the Back Teachers' Superannuation scheme from which we are at present excluded because we are employed by the Federal Government. Some progress has been made along this line and it is felt by some
That if we had an organization through which to work we might succeed in our aim.

A few of the teachers said that they are in the habit of attending the local convention of white school teachers but have found that these conventions do not prove so very helpful to teachers of Indian schools.

Earlier this month I was in Regina and spent some time with Mr. Christianson. He read the replies I had received to my letter and then suggested that I write to you telling you what has been done and asking for your advice on the matter.

The teachers are all agreed that a convention would be of great help in our work and I would like to see some action along this line.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Miss Hodgson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 24th instant, in which you discuss the desirability of organizing a convention of teachers employed at Indian day schools in the province of Saskatchewan.

You may be interested to learn that a comparatively small group of Indian day school teachers employed at our schools in western Ontario have held a convention annually during the last three or four years. The attendance at such conventions is, however, as you can readily suppose, very small, and it is exceedingly difficult to create at these conventions the enthusiasm usually in evidence at the larger conventions of public school teachers. If the conventions you have in mind were called during the holiday period, the Department could have no valid objection. I am personally of the opinion, however, that the costs involved would prove in many cases almost prohibitive.

I am particularly anxious, however, that no misunderstanding should exist in respect to certain matters that might come up for discussion at such a conference, if it were held. The question of establishing a superannuation fund for teachers employed at Indian day and residential schools has come up for discussion and review on at least a dozen occasions since I entered the Department 5 years ago. I have taken a personal interest in this matter, in the hope that ways and means would be found of enabling our teachers to qualify for superannuation allowances. I am convinced that, for the time being at least, the obstacles standing in the way of a superannuation act are insurmountable. This matter has been discussed with groups of teachers, with representatives of the churches and with representatives of teachers' organizations throughout the Division, and no group at this date has submitted a plan that would be likely to prove practicable and acceptable to the churches on the one hand and the government on the other. In this connection I am sending forward, for your personal information, copy of a letter dated April 3, 1939, directed to the Minister of Education in Saskatchewan by the Minister of Mines and Resources. If it were difficult to establish such a fund in normal times, it is not likely that greater consideration will be given to the creation of such a fund at a time when this nation is fighting for its existence.

In respect to the curriculum now in use at Indian schools in the various provinces, I may state that

Miss Florence M. Hodgson,
Sintaluta, Sask.
the Inspector of Indian Schools in the province of British Columbia, who is an employee of this Department, has over a period of 4 or 5 years completely reorganized the courses of study at his schools. I am sending forward also, for your information, a number of excerpts taken from his most recent reports to the Department. I am convinced that the courses of study now in force at our schools in British Columbia will compare favourably with courses of study anywhere in the Dominion.

We have now on our staff here a man who has had 28 years' experience in public school work. This man has also had years of experience in vocational instruction. He is engaged at present in a study of the curriculum in use at present day schools in the other provinces of the Dominion. He is making a complete study, also, of the textbooks in use at our schools, including supplementary readers. He has already prepared a text book dealing with the conservation of wild life, for use in our own schools. This book is now in the hands of the publishers. It is our hope that the funds at our disposal will enable this official to visit a number of our schools in the immediate future. We shall be glad to welcome suggestions from our teachers at any time. No doubt, many of these suggestions will prove valuable in working out new courses of study.

I am sending forward a copy of this letter to the General Superintendent of Indian Agencies at Regina, Mr. Christianson. It is just possible that you may desire to discuss this matter with him again before reaching a decision.

Lionel Grey started school in Sept. 1935 when 8 years of age. He attended 980 days - the equivalent of almost 5 school years. When he left school in June 1942 he was in Grade 5 and ready to enter Grade 6.

Floyd Grey started school in June 1936 at the age of 6 years. He attended 959 days - equal to 4 3/4 school years. When he left school in June 1942 he was in Grade 4.

Alan Grey started school in May 1935 at the age of 7 years. He attended 696 days or 3 1/2 school years. When he left school in June 1942 he was in Grade 3.

Elsie Grey started school in April 1939 just a few days after her fifth birthday. There is no record of her birth in the office here, and I was given to understand that Elsie was nearly 6 when she started school. In the first year I found her exceedingly slow and she learned very little more than just kindergarten work. In the following year when she was 6 she started the regular school work and when she left in June 1942 she was in Grade 2. Elsie attended 452 days or 2 1/4 school years.
I may say that as far as their work was concerned I found the two older children, Lionel and Floyd, to be above average. Alan and Elsie were just average.

For some years I have maintained that the slowness of Indian children—their inability to concentrate for any length of time—is due to the fact that most, if not all of them suffer from malnutrition. I feel sure the reason the Grey children have done so well in the town school has been in part due to the fact that since their father joined the army their children have been better nourished than ever before.

I might also add that during the time I have been in charge of this school we have had regular visits from Provincial School Inspectors and their report on the progress of the children has been, on the whole, satisfactory. One Inspector who visited us for several years sometimes gave the children tests that had been especially prepared for use in white schools. This Inspector expressed himself as pleased with the results obtained by the Indian children. Knowing Mrs. Grey as I do, I am quite sure that any school Inspector would be a much better judge of what was being done in a school.

I found there were thirty-one children on the roll call and at the time of my visit there were twenty-eight present. The average attendance during the last quarter was a little over twenty-three and the previous quarter there were a little over twenty-eight.

The children all looked well and appeared to be well dressed. I was informed by the teacher, Miss F. Hodgson, that the biscuits that are being furnished now by the Department are real good. A mid-day meal is given at this school and the teacher told me several of the children who were below weight when they came in the Fall have gained during the Winter time.

While I was at the school Miss Hodgson had the children go through their work and I was well pleased with what I saw. I believe the school is well conducted and good work is being carried on.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Re Assiniboine Day School.

I wish to report on the Assiniboine Day School and also to recommend some changes regarding it.

The Assiniboine school has been in operation for well over 40 years and during that time the Indian parents have given the school good support and there is no doubt that these Indians prefer this type of school in preference to the Boarding school, in fact it has always been somewhat of a task to get the parents to send their children away to school, to substantiate this statement I may say that even now some of the Indian parents are sending their children over six miles to this school in preference to having their children away from home, at present 9 of the pupils travel 6 miles to school and 11 more over 3½ miles.

During the month of December we had 30 pupils on the roll, with an average attendance of 32.5%, but this month we have 41 on the roll and the average will be possible be 35%, we also have 5 or 6 more children ready for school but these cannot be admitted as the school room is already overcrowded, I may say that 30 pupils would be sufficient for this school room.

We have a building at this point that used to be the Agent's office and more recently used as a residence for the school teacher, but the present teacher is boarding with the Farming-Instructor and wife, this building is 28 x 30', built on a full size basement, with furnace installed, this building is divided as per enclosed sketch.

I would recommend that the room on the east be used as a class room and a second teacher be engaged, this teacher could be in charge of the junior grades, that is grades 1 and 2, there being 21 pupils at present in these two grades, if these junior grades were removed from the present school room it would allow us sufficient floor space.
for thirty pupils.

If a second teacher was employed, the teacher could occupy the other two rooms in the building.

The cost of alterations to the room so as to be able to use it for school purposes would be approximately $200.00; this would cover the cost of having three more windows built in the east wall, blackboards installed and the finished room two coats of paint. 15 more schools desks would be required for children ranging from six to eight years old.

The following items would also have to be inserted in the yearly estimates:
8 tons coal @ $0.200 per ton $64.00
10 loads wood @ $3.00 " load $30.00
Hauling coal @ $1.50 " ton $15.00
Sawing wood @ $1.25 " load $12.50

If the Department decide to operate a two room day school it would be an advantage to operate a school van; a school van route could be planned so as to pick up all pupils who live more than two miles from the school; the use of a van would of course practically make the attendance 100% and would improve the punctuality.

We used to operate a school van at this point but no doubt to curtail expenses it was done away with; one of the Indians drove the van at a monthly salary of $45.00.

We have one or two Indians on this reserve who have fairly good trucks and no doubt one of them could be engaged for this purpose.

Frank Booth,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Titus:

Assiniboine Indian Day School.

I have for answer your letter of July 15th with regard to the above Indian Day School.

Your suggestion concerning the visits of your Superintendents to these schools is entirely satisfactory. We would be pleased if you would instruct your Superintendents to make a visit to the Indian Schools in their respective areas at least once a year. In fact, if a teacher has just graduated from Normal School and is in need of some assistance, we would be prepared to pay for two visits a year.

With regard to Indian schools in the unorganized areas of northern Saskatchewan, it is expected that this matter will be the subject of further correspondence.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard N. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

October 17th, 1933

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter No. IO2-I-4 dated July 25th, 1933 regarding mid-day meal for the children attending the Assiniboine Day School; I may say that I consider it almost impossible to have a day school approach to anything like success without some kind of a mid-day meal as some of the pupils walk four miles to school and to expect the pupils to be bright and pay attention to their studies after their mid-day of one biscuit is out of the question whereas if a bowl of soup be given it would no doubt be a lot more nourishing and palatable.

As you no doubt are aware that a considerable proportion of the pupils are always somewhat under-nourished, and if the mid-day meal in winter is abolished it might mean some of the children becoming on the sick list and the cost of providing for one sick child would more than offset the whole cost of the few supplies necessary.

For $50.00 I could purchase sufficient ingredients to provide a bowl of soup for every pupil attending school all the winter months. As I anticipate an average attendance of 20 for the next 120 school days it would only cost 1½ cents per meal for each pupil. I certainly would be pleased to have authority to purchase supplies for the amount of $50.00.

I am enclosing a letter from Doctor Ismane.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Booth
Indian Agent

Ottawa, November 10, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th ultimo, regarding the midday meal for the children attending the Assiniboine Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that you may incur an expenditure, not exceeding approximately $30.00, in the purchase of the necessary ingredients to provide a bowl of soup for the pupils attending this school during the winter months. You should arrange for the purchase of the supplies required from time to time, obtaining itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It is considered that the preparing and serving of the soup should be for the winter months only. It might be advisable to consult the teacher concerning the supplies necessary for this purpose. The serving of the soup to the pupils at midday should be commenced as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Booth:

In regard to the school children attending the summer day school, I would advise very strongly that a midday meal be given the children especially with the onset of the cold weather. Dear Sir:

With reference to the Day School on the Assiniboine Reserve, I should be very pleased to receive authority to purchase the following supplies:

| Item     | Quantity | Cost |
|----------|----------|------|
| rice     | 100 lbs  | $8.00|
| beef     | 300 lbs  | $18.00|
| barley   | 50 lbs   | $5.00|
| onions   | 1 bag    | $2.50|
| salt     | 1 lb     | $.25 |
| pepper   |          | $.25 |

so as to enable us to provide a mid-day meal for the pupils.

Owing to a total crop failure on the Assiniboine Reserve, some of the Indians will find it very difficult to provide the necessary food to maintain the health and strength of their children, especially the children with far to go to school during the winter months.

The small amount these supplies would cost would no doubt be considerably less than having to provide medical attention in case any sickness occurred amongst them through malnutrition, also more regular attendance would be noticed.

I am enclosing herewith letter received from Dr. Isman.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Day School - Carry-the-Kettle Reserve

The girls in this school are being taught knitting, sewing, etc., but the boys are getting no training in manual science.

There is a full sized basement in this building, which is used for cooking and serving the noon-day meal. This basement is well lighted and suited for manual training.

I would suggest that tools be furnished this school and the boys started in this work next season.

I believe the Farming Instructor, Mr. Hough, who I have asked to have transferred to this Reserve, would be quite competent to instruct. He could give one-half day each week during the winter season without interfering with his other work.

There is also a splendid craft worker on this Reserve whom I believe could be secured to give instruction in craft work.

Submitted for your consideration.

Yours very truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:-

With reference to letter # IO2-I-5 of May 8th 1937, I wish to report that the Assiniboine Day School has not been painted for over 15 years and the siding is not only cracking through lack of paint but it has a very dilapidated appearance, the fence around the grounds is also badly broken down.

With regards to the white-washing of the basement and the kalsoming of the school-room, this is an annual necessity, not only to give it a good appearance but from a health standpoint.

I may say that I have asked to have this school painted for a number of years, but so far it has not been allowed, therefore I hope you will grant it this year has I consider it would be money well spent.

Regina, June 10th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that I visited Carry-the-Kettle Reserve at Sintaluta on Tuesday May 11th.

DAY SCHOOL

Yards, school room and basement, which is used for cooking and serving the mid-day meals, are scrupulously clean. The children are clean and neat in appearance. The school building is badly in need of paint, both inside and out. The window sashes are very loose and should be repaired. The building could be painted and put into first class shape at a cost of not more than $100.00.

SCHOOL GARDEN

Each child has a plot of his own, in addition there is a potato patch. The girls in addition to the other duties are taught knitting etc. This is a good teacher, doing good work.

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir,

Owing to continuous crop failures for the past decade, the Cree and Ojibway peoples are unable to afford the expenses of educating their children. Their children have been attending the Montmartre Convent School.

They will have three more of school age for the coming term and Mr. Kennedy will have one - making a total of seven children from this corner.

The parents will have no other alternatives but to send them to the Day School on our Reserve. They are not in favor of sending their children to Residential Schools, but their homes are from five to six miles from the Day School.

Will you kindly take the matter up with the Indian Department and ask if they could arrange for a van to haul them to and from School.

If these children were attending a Residential School, it would cost the Indian Department about $1000 per annum and the services of a van would only cost about a quarter of this amount.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach a letter received from Dan Kennedy, the most progressive member of the Assiniboine Reserve, Qu'Appelle Agency.

On enquiry, I find that conditions on this Reserve with regard to the Day School are that the new front and back supplied this year will make it possible for the School to seat 31 pupils. Twenty-five children who attended last year will attend this year; in addition there are nine beginners and fourteen others all within reasonable walking distance of the School, who wish to attend this year, making a total of forty-eight children for thirty-one seats.

Mr. Booth some time ago asked for some additional desks, but was advised no funds were available. Consequently, with the exception of the thirty-one, the remainder will have to go to Boarding School. With nine new desks, the School could seat forty, which would be the limit of seating accommodation. If these nine desks could be supplied, a considerable saving would be effected.

In view of the foregoing, when we have more children within walking distance of the School than we can accommodate, I cannot see that any consideration can be given to Mr. Kennedy's request.

School conditions on this Reserve will be covered in a separate letter.
