COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., Aug. 29, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Re: School Conditions, Assiniboine Reserve,
Qu'Appelle Agency.

On the above-mentioned Reserve we have an old school building in a very good state of preservation, with seating accommodation for 31 pupils. The school could accommodate 40 if additional seats were provided.

There are 80 children of school age on the Reserve, and Mr. Booth, Agent, informs me that this number will be increased. The children are about 50% R.G. and 50% Protestant. Mr. Booth informs me that practically all the parents on this Reserve object to sending their children to a residential school. They want to send them to day schools. I have been personally approached by a member of the Band asking that his children be discharged from the residential school and allowed to attend the day school.

It is my opinion that serious consideration should be given to the construction of another school on this Reserve, and that this school should contain two rooms for teaching with a full basement equipped for cooking, manual training, etc. This school should also, in my opinion, be erected on the centre of the Reserve about one and one-half miles from the location of the present school.

As stated before, the present school is in very good condition and the present conditions could be overcome by building a one-room school and continuing to use the present one, but in that event I believe it would be advisable to have the present school moved to a central......

The Secretary,

moved to a central location, as this would allow the employment of one R.C., and one Protestant teacher and avoid any religious dispute that might result otherwise, although Mr. Booth informs me that for years both R.C.'s and Protestants have been attending the same school on this Reserve without any friction.

The establishment of this school would meet the wishes of the people and at the same time relieve the congestion in our residential schools.

Submitted for your consideration.

Yours truly,

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 26, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th instant and also requisition for certain supplies, necessary for the repair of the Assiniboine Indian Day School, attached thereto.

You are authorized to purchase the supplies, a list of which is contained on the requisition. It is noted that Indian labour will be employed.

I must express regret at the failure of the Department to reach a decision with respect to this matter until now. It is my hope, however, that you may be able to proceed with these repairs while the school is open and in operation.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Should we have new authority for this expenditure?
Ottawa,
May 13, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your voucher No. 20 for $10.00 covering the cost of midday meal supplies for the Assiniboine School for the month of April. You quote as your authority official letter of December 1, 1939.

Instructions were issued to all Indian Agents some time ago to the effect that new authority for expenditures such as the above should be secured in each fiscal year.

At the time the authority was originally granted for supplying a midday meal at this school certain conditions were in existence that apparently made such action advisable. However, it is possible that these conditions have changed and there may be no great necessity for supplying a midday meal at this school every month throughout the academic year. As a matter of fact the funds at our disposal are so limited that they do not permit our supplying midday meals except during the winter months.

I presume that you have already arranged for midday meal supplies for the month of May but no such expenditure should be made for the month of June. Before this school re-opens on October 1 you should write to me giving your reasons for desiring a midday meal served at this school and also stating at that time the number of months during which it should be served.

Yours truly,

Mr. F. Booth,
Indian Agent,
Muscow, Sask.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
